terms.definition:
A White Speaker's Sojourn is a campaign variant introduced in the Gambler's Chest Expansion.

A White Speaker's Sojourn.
A White Speaker has joined the settlement as directed by her elders. She must live as a member of the community — eating, learning, and helping — until the survivors reach their bitter end, and then she may leave.

On lantern year 1 of a new campaign, gain +1 population. The White Speaker is treated like any other survivor but gains additional bonuses as she reaches Hunt XP milestones:

Milestone 1: Gain the Leyline Walker ability
Milestone 2: Gain +1 strength, evasion, and accuracy
Milestone 3: Gain the Peerless ability
Milestone 4: Gain the Ageless ability

The White Speaker may not participate in Intimacy, nor gain the benefit of reaching max understanding. A White Speaker in a campaign with arc survivors may adopt a philosophy and gain lumi just as any other survivor from the community would.

Lore.
The Abyssal Woods exists on the precipice of obliteration, its heavy limbs pulled inexorably towards a black hole at its center, no larger than a grain of sand. The hole breathes, as though it were a living being. Every inhale threatens to devour the forest, an intense vacuum rips roots from the ground and sucks waves of tumbling debris through the air. 

Everything that lives in the Abyssal Woods evolves to survive the tantrums of a tiny, unpredictable orifice at its center. Insects with opposable thumbs cling tenaciously to trees, whose roots have become powerful, gnarled hands firmly gripping the ground. Seasoned visitors carry chains and hooks to secure themselves at a moment's notice to the largest things in sight when the winds pick up.

The Flower Witch flickers through the woods, tending to inscrutable tasks that keep it from swallowing itself. Her seemingly random alterations create wonder and death for foolhardy travelers. A coven of disciples assists in the care of the Abyssal Woods; clearing trails, calming boiling rivers, balancing bacterial colonies, and most importantly, clearing the clots from the infinity web that encloses the vacuum at the heart of the forest.Kingdom Death Store Descriptions for Flower Witch and Disciples of the Witch, Recorded on Vibrant Lantern

Gameplay.
Survivors visit the Abyssal Woods when hunting the Flower Knight or Spidicules monsters, although it appears to be a more tame section of the Abyssal Woods, as the survivors don't have to deal with the vacuum at the center of the woods. These two expansions will be required expansions for the Abyssal Woods expansion, while the Dung Beetle Knight and Honeycomb Weaver will have optional interactions with the expansion.

The Abyssal Woods expansion was announced during the Kingdom Death: Monster 1.5 Kickstarter.Kingdom Death: Monster 1.5 Kickstarter, Update #40 The Abyssal Woods was originally teased with the release of the Flower Witch and the Disciples of the Witch models on the Kingdom Death store. The update also shows the Dragon Goblin to perhaps be the main showdown monster of the campaign.

Ambitionism is a Tier 3 Philosophy in the Gambler's Chest Expansion.

Thrive.
Spoiled: If you are a returning survivor and collective cognition did not increase during the Aftermath, skip the next hunt and sulk.

Privileged: Your tenet knowledge will be determined by the Rank 1 result.

Rank 1 - Favored Child.
Gain +1 courage and +3 lumi. Roll 1d10.

CC 41 - Introspection.
If there are any other Ambitionists in the settlement, nominate one. You both gain +1 strength and become rivals. Add Rivalry to the next lantern year on the timeline and nominate yourself and your rival.

Rank 2 - Upstart.
Gain +1 understanding and +3 lumi. Roll 1d10.

Rank 3 - Destiny.
Gain +3 lumi and roll 1d10.

Rank 4 - Shine.
Roll 1d10.

The Ammo Slave is a limited release resin miniature.

Store Description.
When a lauded Great Game Hunter house falls to ruin, their loss is compounded by generations of shame. The fallen family is stripped of its heraldry and its lineage is sold into servitude among the remaining houses. The highest patriarch to the lowliest footman are given ignoble roles, as weapon caddies or cannon fodder to maximize their public humiliation. 

Contents.
1 x Ammo Slave resin figure
1 x Hard plastic 30mm base and insert
Large matte print of the original concept artwork on heavy card stock

Arc People of the Stars is a campaign variant introduced in the Gambler's Chest Expansion. It describes rules for adding arc survivors to a People of the Stars campaign.

Arc People of the Stars.
Arc survivors have a very difficult time developing the traits the Dragon King seeks. Each survivor will need an arc survivor record sheet and a way to track their dragon traits. Do not use the Dreamism Core philosophy, as it is unique to the People of the Dream Keeper campaign.

Arc People of the Sun is a campaign variant introduced in the Gambler's Chest Expansion. This variant describes the rules for adding Arc Survivors to the People of the Sun Campaign.

Arc People of the Sun.
Arc survivors can be added to this campaign. They will partake in their First Meal around the Sacred Pool instead of underneath the Keeper of Dreams. Do not use the Dreamism Core philosophy, as it is unique to the People of the Dream Keeper campaign.

Arc survivors awaken with their minds unshackled. Three interconnected components represent their faculties: Philosophy, Knowledge, and Collective Cognition.

Philosophies are the way arc survivors make sense of their experiences. When they come of age, arc survivors adopt a philosophy that guides how they grow and change in response to their nightmare existence.

Knowledges are skills that can be learned and taught. Often they arise from insight gleaned from an arc survivor's philosophy. Arc survivors' intellectual capacity allows these skills to evolve with experience and to benefit the settlement beyond one survivor's lifetime.

Collective Cognition is the growing potential of a settlement that comes from the neurological benefits of a diverse and nutritious diet.

These three elements build on one another to create a unique experience for arc survivors. Collective Cognition generates new philosophies that add new knowledges. Arc survivors are an optional component; they can be added to any campaign.

Adding Arc Survivors.
To add arc survivors to a new campaign, use the arc survivor settlement and survivor record sheets.

Add First Meal to lantern year 1 of the timeline on the arc settlement record sheet.
Replace Principle: Romantic with Principle: Romantic (Arc) and Sculpture with Sculpture (Arc).
Replace 1 basic hunt event card with Arc Survivor Hunt Event in the basic hunt event deck.
Replace Murder with Murder (Arc) and Skull Eater with Skull Eater (Arc) in the settlement event deck.
Use Intimacy (Arc) instead of Intimacy (Story Event).
During the settlement phase, use the arc survivor settlement board to hold new arc survivor decks.

Current Campaign.
Arc survivors introduce significant changes to your settlement and gameplay. They cannot be added mid-campaign.

People of the Dream Keeper.
Only arc survivors live in The Gambler's settlement. The People of the Dream Keeper campaign uses many of the new components in the Gambler's Chest Expansion, including arc survivors. Complete rules for the setting up the campaign are in the People of the Dream Keeper Campaign section.

Arc Survivors Are Different.
The lives of arc survivors are packed with new aptitudes and their difficult consequences. Arc survivors do not age like other survivors; instead their development is shaped by their philosophies. These new-found freedoms and stresses are represented by new attributes.

Arc Survivor Attributes.
Systemic Pressure: A manifestation of physical stress that accumulates. When survivors make a severe injury roll, subtract their systemic pressure from the roll result.

Torment: A manifestation of ongoing mental strain that accumulates. When survivors make a brain trauma roll, subtract their torment from the roll result.

Torment and systemic pressure are cumulative like other attributes. If a survivor has 1 torment and then gains +1 torment, they then have 2 torment. Arc survivors' knowledges and neuroses can also persistently alter these attributes. If they are removed, their effects on torment and systemic pressure are also removed.

Lumi.
Lumi is the spark of curiosity that proliferates knowledge. Lumi is accrued and spent like survival.

Arc Survivors Age Differently.
Philosophies replace the Age story event that other survivors trigger as they develop. Although arc survivors still get older, the way they change with age is determined by their philosophy.

Arc Survivors and Weapon Proficiency.
Arc survivors do not choose weapon proficiencies as a result of the Age story event. Instead, weapon proficiencies result from collective cognition rewards.

The Forum Settlement Location.
As their collective cognition increases, arc survivors earn a Forum location in their settlements. The Forum is dedicated to knowledge. At the Forum, survivors learn and share knowledges and help others along their philosophical journeys.

The Azure Knight is a Generic Hero Class resin miniature.

Store Description.
The Azure Knight is the result of a collaboration between Adam & Lokman, exploring some well established tropes in fantasy art. Originally intended as a small line of Generic Hero Classes, the results were so compelling and un-generic, each hero's appearance told so many exciting stories that we wanted to integrate them into the KD world but so far nothing concrete has emerged. 

She always heard stories of how her older sister left home on the day of her birth to be initiated into the stoic sect of the Azure knights. These fighters emanated the invigored breeze of hope for her people who live shrouded in otherwise darkness and stagnant air. Throughout childhood she made sure to follow the Azure Knight's code, showing unwavering grace and civility to all those around her.

On the day her sister’s sword was brought back home by a mysterious messenger, she decided it was time, no matter how young she may be, to discover what happened to her estranged sibling. Under the cover of night she stole the heavy blade. The sword of the Azure Knights was known to cut through any shadow with a sharp gust of vehemence and might. Instilling in it’s wielder a clear, blue vision of their future victory against the dankest of adversaries. With scraps of cloth and bones of animals salvaged near her family’s home she sewed herself the uniform of the Azure Knights and departed on the the same path her sister took so many years ago. In search of an answer in the dark.

Contents.
1 x Resin Azure Knight
1 x Hard Plastic Kingdom Death 30mm round base & insert
Large matte print of the original concept artwork on heavy card stock
Character art card

Before the Wall is a white box expansion for the Kingdom Death: Monster Core Game. It features content that integrates with the core game and depicts the female survivor Aya.

Store Description.
The next installation in the series of sculptures following the exploits of Aya the Survivor. Before the Wall represents the start of Aya's journey. She is armed with a Black Sword and Beacon Shield. Her deadly weapons suggest a powerful quarry waiting for Aya at the end of her hunt.

Contents.
1x Hard plastic Before the Wall
1x Hard plastic 30mm round base with insert
1x Vagabond Armor armor set card 
1x Tabard and White Dragon Gauntlets gear cards
Large matte print of the original concept artwork on heavy card stock

Notes.
The White Dragon Gauntlets require a settlement location called Ivory Carver that does not yet exist within the game. Additionally, the gauntlets feature a gear special rule called Sideswipe, which also does not currently exist in the game.

See Also.
Beyond the Wall
Survivor (Female)

Beyond the Wall is a white box expansion for the Kingdom Death: Monster Core Game. It features content that integrates with the core game and features the female survivor Aya.

Store Description.
This diorama continues the story of Aya the Survivor. Although released first, this sculpt finds Aya battered and on the run, hiding behind convenient rubble from an unseen foe. We have reissued Beyond the Wall to accompany the release of Before the Wall, a new figure chronicling earlier (more hopeful) moments of Aya's journey.

Contents.
1x Hard plastic Beyond the Wall miniature
1x Hard plastic unique scenic base
1x Hard Breastplate and Cloth Leggings gear cards
Large matte print of the original concept artwork on heavy card stock

Limited Release.
Beyond the Wall was originally released as a limited release resin miniature with a First Run of 250 miniatures. Since the release of the Beyond the Wall white box, the resin miniature is no longer released as an Encore.

terms.term: Black Friday Black Grab Bag of Death
terms.definition:
is a limited release bundle that contained unreleased, and miscast Kingdom Death miniatures.

Store Description.
A chance to mine the hidden history of Kingdom Death. Along the way, this project has yielded some models that while lovely, will not be sold or produced. We've also amassed an enormous collection of miscasts and incomplete figures that cannot be sold but with a little love from an ambitious modeller could be great for conversions or hobby projects.
We have put together a grab bag containing an assortment of KD history. The photos show grab bag #0017 and its contents. After photographing, all the parts were returned to the bag and it was added to the lot.

Contents.
Grab bags were not created equally and include:
1x random never-to-be released figure (complete and well-cast)
Great Game Hunter early variant
Mother early variant
Male Savior early variant
An assortment of roughly 4 figures that are almost complete or partially miscast
Blessed One
Pinup Preacher
54mm Pinup Preacher
Original Forsaker
White Speaker Koshka
Preacher
Savior
Twilight Relic Knight early variant
Twilight Order Knight early variant
Surprise bits!
??????

The Black Knight Squire (Male) is a limited release resin miniature.

Store Description.
For generations, the Black Knight has unknowingly defended a settlement of people hidden in the ruins of it's home. They have become self-appointed loyal squires, creating a position of honor that wears the heraldry of the knight and secretly toils in its service. When invaders appear, the squires watch from the shadows so they may treasure the lessons of their master.

Contents.
1 x Resin Black Knight Squire - Male
1 x Hard plastic Kingdom Death 30mm base and Insert 
1 x 6" x 4" Matte art print

is a Generic Hero Class resin miniature.

Store Description.
The Boxer continues the collaboration between Adam & Lokman, exploring some well established tropes in fantasy art. Originally intended as a small line of Generic Hero Classes, the results were so compelling and un-generic, each hero's appearance told so many exciting stories that we wanted to integrate them into the KD world but so far nothing concrete has emerged. 

The Boxer's people forage the papery substance founds in the claustrophobic nests of the giant golden-boned hornets. Shining with imperious light, paper made of the nest turns any writing on it from prophecy to fate. 

Confrontations between hornets and invaders in the nest inevitably lead to the annihilation of the fragile paper, leading foragers to cultivate stealth. Unfortunately, the Boxer's bravado often left her scrapping wildly with hornets, leaving pitiful shreds of wasted treasure flapping on the hot winds. 

After yet another disaster, she scrawled the number one on a speck of paper husk stuck to her bloodied fists.That is the moment, the Magnificent Contest of Fists came to be. Without hesitation, she raced to meet her destiny.
Store Description 1

The Boxer's people forage the papery substance founds in claustrophobic nests of giant golden-boned hornets. Shining with imperious light, paper made of the nests center turns any writing on it from prophecy to fate. 

Confrontations between hornets and invaders in the nest inevitably lead to the annihilation of the fragile paper maze, leading foragers to cultivate a unique combat style. Utilizing large soft gloves and sharp upper body movements, ruinous puncture damage was minimized while hornets were knocked out, preventing their death pheromone from sending the nest into a destructive frenzy. 

A maze nest is only completed once a year and the people hold a tournament to determine the select elites whom will have the opportunity to carefully wander its layered halls boxing their way to riches and fame.

Character card back/front, from the Gambler's Chest Expansion.]]
Characters introduce new dimensions to the survivors living in the shadow of the mightiest settlements. Powerful progenitors have changed the very landscape, leaving traces that shape future settlements.

Characters explore unique quirks and idiosyncrasies that shape survivors beyond their blank slate.

Unlocking Characters.
Characters are not available for immediate use. After players defeat the Godhand in a People of the Dream Keeper campaign, they unlock Characters for subsequent campaigns in the Epilogue story event.

Adding Characters.
To add Characters to a new campaign, add Character (Innovation) to your game box. It is earned as a consequence of Inner Lantern.

Building the Character Deck.
The Character deck represents the best and worst of your settlement. When your settlement innovates Character, create the character deck using character cards from your collection.

The deck must have a minimum of 24 cards.
For every 1 impairment type card you may add up to 5 ability type cards to the deck.
After constructing the deck, you may add 1 legendary ability card.

Character Cards.
Name: The name of the ability or impairment.

Type: Ability, impairment, or legendary ability.

Rules: The rules that immediately apply to the survivor. They can include existing abilities/impairments, attribute modifications, disorders, or new states unique to this character trait.

Gaining Character Cards.
After the settlement innovates Character, draw a random character card from the settlement's deck whenever a survivor is named.

When a survivor draws a character card, they gain the listed ability or impairment, recording the name and rules on their character record sheet. Then return the character card to the deck.

Food is central in arc survivor settlements. Arc survivors live to enrich their diets, and in return, their well-nourished brains can collectively achieve new heights of power and sophistication.

This cultural growth is represented by collective cognition (CC). As the settlement reaches higher amounts of CC, they earn rewards.

Survivors acquire collective cognition by defeating a mix of challenging monsters. More challenging monsters proffer greater collective cognition.

Gaining CC from Quarry Monsters.
Quarry monsters stalking the darkness offer a powerful incentive for hungry arc survivors. Older, tougher monsters are a feast for ravenous arc cells. If they defeat a monster, the victorious survivors return to the settlement with food and the potential for profound change. Victorious survivors gain CC in the Aftermath of the Showdown. Once the Aftermath is resolved, update the Settlement Victories section on the arc settlement record sheet. Next to the name of the defeated quarry, fill an unfilled box under its level. Update the total collective cognition above. If no box remains unfilled for that monster's level, the settlement gains no CC.

Lv. 1 quarry monsters provide 1 CC the first time they are defeated.
Lv. 2 quarry monsters provide 2 CC the first 2 times they are defeated.
Lv. 3+ quarry monsters provide 3 CC the first 3 times they are defeated.

Gaining CC from Nemesis Monsters.
Menacing forces invading the settlement do not provide the same kinds of enrichment. They contribute to the collective cognition (3 CC) only the first time each level is defeated. Defeating the same level nemesis multiple times generates no additional CC.

Legendary Monsters.
Legendary monsters are singular existences that are not standard quarry monsters. The settlement gains 3 CC after defeating one.

Collective Cognition Rewards.
When a settlement eats well, its collective cognition increases. This can add new cultural benefits for arc survivors, which are found on CC Reward cards.

CC Reward Cards.
CC Reward cards are gained when the settlement reaches a specific amount of collective cognition.

The back of each CC Reward card has a number indicating the collective cognition needed to gain the card. The front of each card contains the rules for gaining the reward.

Quarry Monster CC Rewards.
Quarry monster rewards have a collective cognition number corresponding to their node. The node represents the order these quarry monsters appear in the story of your campaign.

Create the CC Rewards Deck.
Organize all CC Rewards cards according to the numbers on the backs, from lowest to highest, so that the lowest number is on top of the deck, face down.

Include only the quarry monster reward cards for monsters in your campaign. Examine cards 6, 16, 26 and 36.

For the People of the Dream Keeper campaign, include the Crimson Crocodile, Smog Singers, Phoenix, and King. Set the other monster CC Rewards aside.

Unique CC Rewards.
There can never be more than one card with the same collective cognition number in the deck. In cases where duplicates remain, choose one.

Record CC Rewards.
Once your deck is complete, record the name of each CC Reward in the space provided on the arc settlement record sheet in numerical order.

Gaining CC Rewards.
The settlement gains collective cognition rewards during the Check Milestones step of the settlement phase. Compare the collective cognition total to the top card of the CC Rewards deck. The settlement gains any cards with numbers less than or equal to the settlement's collective cognition.

For each CC reward gained, follow the rules listed on the card and update the settlement accordingly. Find the reward listed in the Collective Cognition Rewards section of the arc settlement record sheet; fill in the box next to the reward and archive the CC Reward card.

Food Innovations.
One reward of improving collective cognition is innovations of the preparation and culture of food. The only way to gain these innovations is through achieving higher collective cognition. When they reach the pinnacle of food innovation, Supreme Cuisine, they can Endeavor to create meal gear.

Butchery and Arc Survivor Weapon Proficiency.
Arc survivors cannot select a Weapon Proficiency until they have gained the Butchery food innovation. Once earned, they may select a weapon proficiency when they depart for a hunt.

Meal Gear.
Devouring quarries inspires the survivors to craft marvelous recipes. If the settlement has earned at least 10 CC from consuming a quarry, they may endeavor at Supreme Cuisine to craft that monster's meal.

Once a meal is crafted, it can be used by the settlement each lantern year. A survivor may place one meal in their Gear Grid, gaining the monster-inspired effects when they Depart the settlement. A settlement may only have one of each meal gear at any time.

Collective Cognition Reward card back/front, from Gambler's Chest Expansion.]]

The Disciple of the Witch (Four) is a limited release resin miniature.

Store Description.
Everything that lives in the Abyssal Woods evolves to survive the tantrums of a tiny, unpredictable orifice at its center. Insects with opposable thumbs cling tenaciously to trees, whose roots have become powerful, gnarled hands firmly gripping the ground. Seasoned visitors carry chains and hooks to secure themselves at a moment's notice to the largest things in sight when the winds pick up.

Beyond enabling the disciples to survive the hole of the forest, continued wear of their garments deepens a symbiotic relationship, granting them even greater understanding and power. However, an intense caloric intake is required to keep the fabric fed. This can pose a great challenge for young disciples, who often starve to death or are simply consumed by their hat.

Contents.
Resin Disciple of the Witch - Four
Hard Plastic Kingdom Death 30mm Round Base
6" x 4" Matte Art Print
Character Art Card

The Disciple of the Witch - One is a limited release resin miniature.

Store Description.
A coven of disciples that assist in the care of the Abyssal Woods; clearing trails, calming boiling rivers, balancing bacterial colonies, and most importantly, clearing the clots from the infinity web that encloses the vacuum at the heart of the forest.

The staves of the disciples are topped with a dense mineral, so saturated with colors that it appears black to human eyes. The mineral is the heart of a plant that lives in warm nests deep within a great inverted mountain. The Flower Witch teaches its disciples to use their staves to manipulate plant life cycles, commanding them to grow or wither.

Contents.

The Sleeping Flower has 13 petals, which is as many disciples as the Flower Witch will ever keep. However, the fifth petal never uncurls, even when the flower is in full bloom. Its contents are a mystery to all but the Flower Witch, who privately muses that it will be the burden of the disciple that succeeds her, inheriting both her mask and her many mistakes.

Above all else, the Flower Witch teaches the disciples about ego and the beauty of life and death. Cultivating immaculate beauty at the precipice of destruction strengthens the ego needed to wield the Flower Witch’s powers and maintain her knowledge.

Something is hunting the survivors as they hunt their quarry. Encounters with these foes take place during the hunt phase. Encounters can ruin or enrich a hunt. The Gambler's Chest Expansion includes the Bone Eaters encounter monsters.

Encounter Monster Components.
The following components are used for an encounter with the dangerous Bone Eaters:

Encounter hunt event cards
Initiative cards
Opportunity deck
Counter deck
Critical wound deck
Encounter Showdown story event
Reference card
Encounter board
Encounter monster miniatures
Life dice

Adding Encounters.
To add encounters to a new campaign, add each encounter's introduction story event to the indicated lantern year on the timeline of your settlement record sheet.

Current Campaign.
To add encounters to a current campaign, add each encounter's introduction story event to the indicated lantern year on the timeline of your settlement record sheet. If this lantern year has passed, add it to the next lantern year.

Adding Bone Eaters.
Add the introduction story event Missing Statue to lantern year 3 on the settlement's timeline.

Encounter hunt event cards replace basic hunt event cards, introducing the looming threat of an encounter showdown during the hunt.

Initiative cards determine the order in which the monsters act. Each initiative card is illustrated with a specific encounter monster.

Opportunity cards are small cards that add horrifying outcomes to encounter monster basic attacks.

Counter cards are small cards that describe counter measures performed by monsters when they find an opening.

Critical wound cards are small cards that describe what happens when survivors inflict critical wounds on encounter monsters.

The Encounter Showdown story event lists the monsters' attributes and traits, encounter setup diagrams, and the outcomes of the encounter.

Reference cards list essential information that the monster controller uses to pummel the survivors.

The encounter board is a unique board on which encounter showdowns take place.

Life dice are used to track each monster's life total.

There are five Bone Eater miniatures in this expansion. Survivors will battle all of them at once.

Encounter Hunt Events.
When the encounter monster introduction story event is triggered, an encounter hunt event card is introduced into the basic hunt event deck. From this moment, the threat of an encounter looms over every hunt.

Missing Statue replaces a basic hunt event with Bone Eaters - Encounter Level 1 in the basic hunt event deck.

When the encounter hunt event is revealed, if the current lantern year is the same or later than the lantern year on the card, the encounter monsters challenge the survivors and the encounter showdown begins. If the lantern year on the card is in the settlement's future, the monsters are disinterested; roll a random hunt event instead.

Encounter Showdown.
Encounters take place in the claustrophobic darkness of the hunt, somewhere between the settlement and the survivors' quarry.

Encounter Board Setup.
Set up the small encounter board below the hunt board. Leave all hunt phase materials (e.g., hunt board, unrevealed hunt events) on the table.

Turn to the Encounter Showdown story event. Place the terrain, the monsters, and the survivors as specified by the encounter setup diagram for your encounter level.

Place life dice showing the starting life of each encounter monster in that monster's base.

Do not add terrain tiles beyond what is listed in the encounter setup (ignore the effects of Strategist, Bug Trap, etc.).

Set Up Encounter Cards.
Encounter showdown story events list the monsters' attributes and traits for each encounter level.

Place any Special trait cards listed for your encounter level faceup in play alongside the encounter board.

Place the double-sided Basic Action / Reference card and initiative cards nearby. Shuffle the basic resource deck and set it facedown.

Shuffle each deck of opportunity, counter, and critical wound cards and set each nearby. These cards, along with Basic Actions and traits, determine the monsters' behaviors.

The Encounter.
Encounters are showdowns and have the same round structure. The rules in this section highlight the differences between encounters and showdowns. If questions arise, consult the Showdown Phase section in the core game rulebook.

At the beginning of an encounter, survivors gain Arrival and "start of showdown" bonuses. Effects that directly refer to the showdown, such as "during the showdown" effects, are usable during an encounter. All showdowns are unique conflicts, so "once per showdown" effects may be used again during the showdown with the survivors' quarry.

Monster Turn.
All encounter monsters act on the monster turn. At the start of the monster turn, the monster controller shuffles the initiative cards.

Initiative Cards.
The order in which encounter monsters act is determined by initiative cards. The monster controller draws the top initiative card, activating the monster shown. This monster performs its Basic Action. Do this until all monsters have been activated and their turns resolved.

Encounter Monster Basic Action.
Encounter monsters perform their Basic Action one at a time. As they do, they are always searching for an opportunity to get the upper hand. The monsters' Basic Action describes when such an opening occurs.

These opportunities are part of the Basic Action. They describe when the monster will draw an opportunity card. For example, Bone Eaters draw an opportunity card when they roll any Perfect hits.

Opportunity Cards.
When a monster draws an opportunity card, perform it as you would any other card. These are always performed by the currently acting monster and use the target of the Basic Action unless otherwise stated. When an opportunity card is resolved, place it in a discard pile.

Opportunity Card Moods.
Some opportunity cards are monster moods. These follow the same rules as showdown monster moods. Place them in play and apply their persistent rules for as long as the card remains in play. Opportunity moods affect all monsters unless otherwise stated.

Encounter Monsters Are Individual Monsters.
Each encounter monster is its own entity. When rules state that a monster gains an attribute token, only that monster gains a token. Encounter monsters do not share fields of view or adjacency.

Movement & Collision.

Encounter Monster Movement.
When an action instructs an encounter monster to move towards a target, it takes the shortest path possible, moving around survivors, impassable terrain, and other monsters. If no path exists, move the monster as close as possible to its target.

Encounter monsters cannot voluntarily move through spaces occupied by survivors, impassable terrain, or other monsters.

If an encounter monster would occupy a space containing impassable terrain or another monster, place it in the nearest unoccupied space instead.

Encounter Monster Knockback.
When an encounter monster suffers knockback, move it the indicated number of spaces away from the source of the knockback. If the monster would move into impassable terrain or another monster, stop its movement in the last unoccupied space before that object is reached (archive destructible terrain).

Knockback can move an encounter monster through a survivor. When it does, the survivor suffers collision at the end of the monster's movement. If the monster ends its knockback on a space occupied by a survivor, the survivor suffers collision and knockback 5.

Survivor Turn.
Survivors can perform the same actions in an encounter that they perform in a showdown. Encounter monsters do not have hit location decks, but they may still suffer critical wounds.

Attacking Encounter Monsters.
Survivors make attack rolls and determine the number of hits as normal.

Instead of drawing hit location cards for each hit, survivors make a wound attempt roll for each hit, one at a time. On a successful wound attempt, the encounter monster suffers a wound.

When a survivor attacks while multiple encounter monsters are in range, they must choose which encounter monster they are attacking. If an encounter monster moves out of range or dies mid-attack, cancel all remaining hits.

Check for Critical Wounds.
Lantern 10s, luck, and other applicable rules may cause critical wounds as normal.

When the monster receives a critical wound, draw and resolve a critical wound card. If a survivor kills a monster with a critical wound, they still draw and resolve a critical wound card. After resolving it, place the critical wound card in a discard pile.

Wounding Encounter Monsters.
When the encounter monster suffers a wound, reduce the monster's life by 1 (track this using the life dice on the model's base). If the monster's Life reaches 0, it dies. Remove its miniature from the encounter board and archive its initiative card.

Counter Conditions and Counter Cards.
Encounter monsters may counter the survivors' desperate assault. The counter conditions listed on the encounter monster reference card describe the moment this occurs.

When the counter conditions occur, the monster controller draws a counter card and resolves it. After a counter card is resolved, place it in a discard pile.

Survival Opportunities.
Survivors have all the survival opportunities of a monster showdown: on the survivors' turn, during flows, after critical wounds, and when a monster is knocked down. The one exception is survival opportunities during reactions; without a hit location deck, these opportunities do not arise.

When an encounter monster draws an opportunity or counter card, there are no survival opportunities unless a flow is present.

End of the Encounter.
At the end of the encounter, the survivors are either defeated or have reached a crossroads. Since the end of the encounter is not the end of the journey, there is no Aftermath step.

Defeat.
If the hunting party has perished, they suffer defeat. Resolve the rules of defeat on the encounter showdown story event and end your hunt. Continue to the settlement phase.

Victory.
When the survivors are victorious, they gain the listed benefits of victory and rewards. Once they have determined their rewards, they Deliberate their next steps. Survivors retain all tokens and damage accrued during the encounter. Instead of applying any Aftermath rules, they must make a choice:

Resume the hunt. The survivors press on into the darkness, resuming on the hunt board as though they had just resolved a long hunt event.

Return home. The settlement suffers. Place the survivors at Starvation. The hunt ends in failure.

Lower expectations. The survivors can elect to hunt a lower-level quarry. Do not adjust the survivors' or monster's positions on the hunt board. When the showdown begins, the survivors fight a monster one level lower than that of their original quarry. You cannot lower a monster's level to less than 1.

If an effect like Exhausted Lantern Hoard compels the survivors to hunt level 3+ monsters, they cannot choose to fight a monster below level 3.

Encounters Intensify.
Once the encounter monster is defeated, remove the corresponding encounter hunt event card from the basic hunt event deck.

If possible, the threat intensifies. Add the next higher level encounter hunt event card to the deck. If none exists, the threat disappears back into the darkness.

Continue the Hunt.
If the survivors choose to lower their expectations or resume the hunt, return the encounter materials to the game box. The hunt phase resumes.

The Energy Potion Maker is a Generic Hero Class resin miniature.

Store Description.
The Energy Potion Maker is the result of a collaboration between Adam & Lokman, exploring some well established tropes in fantasy art. Originally intended as a small line of Generic Hero Classes, the results were so compelling and un-generic, each hero's appearance told so many exciting stories that we wanted to integrate them into the KD world but so far nothing concrete has emerged.

Born and raised in the riotous bustle of the Sunset Bazaar the Energy Potion Maker is a cunning operator, accepting treasures and rare objects in trade for her potions. Buyers of her brews use them to surmount impossible challenges with an extra boost of energy, specifically crafted for their task. Potion drinker that survive their trials find themselves profoundly exhausted, never knowing that the Energy Potion Maker slyly skims from their life force at the peak of their labors, amassing drops of fiery spirit into a potion reserved for her final challenge.

Contents.
1 x Resin Energy Potion Maker
1 x Hard Plastic Kingdom Death 30mm round insert and base
Large Matte Art Print
Character Art Card

The Estate Hero is a Generic Hero Class resin miniature.

Store Description.
Teeming subterranean caves, dizzying cloud labyrinths, doom, and conquest await inside the dungeon. But, outside the dungeon, mind the property line. Landlords lucky enough to discover a dungeon entrance on their property employ Estate Heroes to tend the grounds, keeping the thoroughfare clear of pests, wandering menaces, and shaking down newly flush heroes for land use taxes.

Accompanied by a long-eared harehound that listens for the jangling pockets of successful adventures, she uses her minor magical abilities for encouraging the growth of elaborate inviting grounds to keep heroes coming through the door.

Contents.
1 x Estate Hero resin figure
1 x Hard plastic 30mm base and resin scenic insert
Large matte print of the original concept artwork on heavy card stock

Experiment of Death was a limited release bundle that was produced to experiment with plastic production for the development of Kingdom Death: Monster.

Store Description.
As part of research and development for the future of Kingdom Death, two of our most popular models are now in PVC plastic!!

Experiment of Death is the first Kingdom Death product in PVC plastic and with its success I look forward to using it as a solution for the final boxed-game minis. I hope you'll love it too! The process ends up shrinking the models by about 3%, so the plastic pinup twilight knight is 1.05mm smaller then her resin incarnation. 

Contents.
PVC Wet Nurse
PVC Pinup Twilight Knight 
2x double-sided matte art cards
1x 30mm plastic base

The Fighter is a Generic resin miniature.

Store Description.
The Fighter is 2nd result of a collaboration between Adam & Lokman, exploring some well established tropes in fantasy art. Originally intended as a small line of Generic Hero Classes, the results were so compelling and un-generic, each hero's appearance told so many exciting stories that we wanted to integrate them into the KD world but so far nothing concrete has emerged.

Perhaps...

the Fighter is a host to parasitic worms that regenerate her body. They make her near-immortal, pale, and her eyes yellow. The worms feed off the water and salt in her body and thus she must consume copious amounts of both to stay alive but the resulting diet keeps her body swollen, obscuring her muscular frame. Her fighting style is sloppy and agressive, unhindered by fear of harm.

Generics are a spin-off miniature line that is the result of a collaboration between Adam Poots, and the lead artist of Kingdom Death, Lokman Lam. The line was intended to explore common fantasy tropes in order to establish generic hero characters, but the results were more compelling than anticipated. Currently the lore associated with each Generic miniature exists outside of the world of Kingdom Death.

The Grand Mother is a limited release resin miniature.

Store Description.
Few chosen victims survive the treatment of raw god metal that prepares a womb to withstand and nurture the ghastly cocktail that gives rise to the monsters of the Holy Lands. The truly holy mothers are beautified as Grand Mothers, transformed into creatures embodying the maternal life-giving ideal of the Entity. These special few give birth to the Entity's most precious children, the massive winged Blessed Ones. The Grand Mother's womb is braced heavy ornate gut plates. Within, a hostile furnace of creation churns. She has a mouthed cord growing from her belly that devours male organs of her mates to better the chances of divine conception. 

The Grand Mother is a rare, horrifying foe, possessing a master the Other and protected by the watchful eye of the Entity itself.

Contents.
1x Resin Grand Mother Miniature
1x Kingdom Death hard plastic 30mm base and insert
1x Character Card

6" x 4" Print of the Original Concept Artwork on heavy card stock

The female Great Game Hunter is a limited release resin miniature.

Store Description.
The Great Game Hunters are aristocrats, cultivated sportsmen who compete for the prestige of killing the most ferocious of monsters.

The Great Game Hunters hail from a bizarrely flourishing city. Many generations of families have survived astonishingly well, growing complacent and wealthy in the city. Beneath the worldly noble exterior of the city, inhuman forces breed intrigue and family rivalries. These hapless noblemen squabble over resources and knowledge risking their lives in competition for prestige, chasing rumors of ever more dangerous game.

Contents.
Great Game Hunter (Female) resin miniature
Alternate hand holding a saber
Kingdom Death base (25mm resin square base in the limited run, 30mm hard plastic round base in encore runs)
Matte art print in a hard plastic casing
Art card

Notes.
Great Game Hunter (Female) was tooled in plastic to be released in the now cancelled Lantern Festival Expansion.

Herb Gathering can refer to:
Herb Gathering (Story Event)
Herb Gathering (Special Hunt Event)

Lore.
The Holy Lands are the domain of a vain being known as the Golden Entity. Populated with great grinding machinery, molten pools of god metal, and a variety of strange beings all seemingly churning towards a singular purpose; to literally give birth to the perfect army.

While there is not a great deal of information available, it should be noted that there are two specific locations referenced as part of the Holy Lands: the Golden Labyrinth, and the Holy City.

The Golden Labyrinth is hinted to be a prison, containing the failure that was the First Lion Knight.

The Holy City is likely the main hub of the Holy Lands, where the bulk of the Golden Entities machines and subjects are headquartered.Kingdom Death store descriptions for various models related to the Holy Lands, recorded at VibrantLantern.com

Gameplay.
The Holy Lands do not appear to be directly referenced in the materials for Kingdom Death: Monster. Instead, all lore has been gleaned from the descriptions of multiple models released for purchase on the Kingdom Death shop.

We do however encounter entities with their origins rooted in the Holy Lands, specifically the White Lion and the Lion Knight.

The church parlors of the order are found almost everywhere but its Holy Mages are an enigma. For exorbitant fees of gold and jewels, the Holy Mage will transform adventurers inside and out. Their knowledge is a closely guarded secret and to protect it, Holy Mages change their own appearance daily leaving their number and identity a mystery.

Homicidalism is a Systemic Philosophy in the Gambler's Chest Expansion. It is added to the philosophy deck by the Murder arc settlement event.

Live to Kill.
Murderer: During the hunt or showdown, if you are ever alone with another survivor, you murder them; keep track of your Body Count on your arc survivor record sheet.

Before resolving each rank of Homicidalism, roll 1d10 and subtract your Body Count from the roll result. On a 1 or lower, the settlement kills you.

Rank 1 - The Beat.
Gain +1 lumi and roll 1d10.

Rank 2 - Signal and Noise.
-1 population. Gain +3 insanity and +1 lumi. Roll 1d10.

CC 12 - Introspection.
Gain the Cruel Cleaver pattern.

Rank 3 - Cacophony.
-1 population (choose the survivor with the highest understanding). Gain +1 lumi and roll 1d10.

Rank 4 - Symphony.
Nominate the survivor with the highest insanity. If the settlement has Partnership, you undergo Shared Psychosis. Otherwise, you Destroy the Prodigal.

Gain +1 lumi and roll 1d10.

The Hospitalar is a Generic Hero Class resin miniature.

Store Description.
Hospitalars are the free knights of the Hospital and consider every land with someone in need to be part of their domain. Often the Hospital, with its vast riches, will coerce its way into a lord’s land so it may setup a fortress for a resident Hospitalar. From there they can offer their advanced surgical and healing services to adventurers as they leave for dungeons or other places of great peril. The Hospital’s power resides the revered Heal Stone, a precious gem that is vomited annually by the Great Oyster Dragon. Each Hospitalar is entrusted with a fragment of the gem as its magical powers fuel their tools.

Contents.
1 x Hospitalar resin figure
1 x Hard plastic 30mm base and insert
Large matte print of the original concept artwork on heavy card stock
Character art card

The Investment Sniper is a Generic Hero Class resin miniature.

Store Description.
The Investment Sniper continues the result of a collaboration between Adam Poots & Lokman, exploring some well established tropes in fantasy art. Originally intended as a small line of Generic Hero Classes, the results were so compelling and un-generic, each hero's appearance told so many exciting stories that we wanted to integrate them into the KD world but so far nothing concrete has emerged. 

The rain of coins that marks the transmutation of the dead into loot is governed by the invisible market forces of the Bank. Calculation and patience are the tools of the Bank’s representatives. The Investment Sniper manages the Bank’s interests, eliminating creatures as loans to promising futures or curating investments of ambitious heroes looking for unusually monstrous paydays. The perpetual presence of the Investment Sniper at the right place and time is furnished by the Bank’s safe, where she deposits her soul in exchange for a seemingly limitless gateway to regions of the Bank’s interests.

Contents.
1 x Investment Sniper resin figure
1 x Hard plastic 30mm base and insert
Large matte print of the original concept artwork on heavy card stock

King's Coins were a digital currency that was released through the Kingdom Death shop. When purchased the buyer was sent a digital code that could be redeemed and its value put towards a purchase, acting as a digital gift card. Unfortunately, the coins were poorly received, and removed from the store with all existing coins refunded.

Store Description.

The King's Coins give you the privilege of a king.

When it is safe to reopen HQ, our next sale will only accept King's Coins as a form of payment for 24 hours! The King's Coins are a gift card, the value of which can be applied to any purchase on the Kingdom Death store. Your King's Coin balance is available for any number of purchases until it is completely depleted.

We reserve the right to add a special miniature in the future which can only be purchased with the King's Coins! (Of course if we do so, we will give everyone another opportunity to purchase King's Coins).

Your purchase of King's Coin's helps support the team as we look forward to returning to the awesome work of making and sending minis to our fans.

Terms and Conditions
King's Coins can only be used on the Kingdom Death online store.
King's Coins are not refundable.
King's Coins do not expire.
King's Coins cannot be redeemed for cash of any kind.
King's Coins cannot be used to buy additional King's Coins.
Responsibility for King's Coins passes to the recepient upon purchase. Kingdom Death is not responsible for any King's Coins that are lost, stolen, destroyed, or used without the recipient's permission.

Withdrawal and Backlash.
 paying for Kingdom Death product using the King's Coins.]]After the release of the King's Coins many fans were confused on their usage and exclusivity. With widespread commenting on their purpose across the communities and on the Kingdom Death kickstarter page. The Kingdom Death team quickly recognized the issues with the coins and withdrew them from the online store, issuing refunds to any customers that purchased them. The store description was then changed to state the following:

I am sorry. The King's Coins were poorly explained and there was a lot confusion and misunderstandings about them. I am going to collect them all (100k worth), melt them down and at some point in the future, mint them again in a much better way. Everyone will be refunded asap. No, we do not need the money. I honestly thought the idea would be fun. Please accept my most humble apologies.

We are refunding you over the weekend.

- Adam Poots

The Kingdom Death: Monster Core Game introduces players to the world of Kingdom Death, while giving them the information necessary to play this unique nightmare horror game.

Store Description.
19 lbs of Nightmare Horror Gaming

235 page hardcover rule book, 18 hard plastic sprues of miniatures, 1000+ matte game cards, 400+ unique pieces of art, and 86 full page illustrations.

Kingdom Death: Monster is a fully cooperative, tabletop, hobby game experience. Unite to survive by hunting monsters and collectively guiding the development of your settlement through a 30 year, self-running campaign.

Every decision matters. A space moved during the showdown, every resource spent to craft a piece of gear, what principles your settlement upholds - all can have lasting impact on this highly replayable and challenging game. 

Campaign System
Embark alone or with up to 4 friends (6 with game variant) on a 30 lantern year campaign. Each lantern year will cycle through a chaotic hunt, a showdown with a monster, and the development of your settlement. With so much emphasis on player choice, no two campaign runs will be alike.

Monster AI System
You will fight 8 monsters, each controlled by their own pair of decks that scale to 3 levels of difficulty. (Except for the final encounter, it has only 1 level and it's HARD!) Every encounter, even with the same monster, is diverse and valuable. No two showdowns will resolve the same way. Players will have to plan their gear and keep their minds sharp to prevail.

Gear System
In Monster, survivors will craft gear using resources earned from defeating monsters or found on their hunt. Each survivor has a gear grid, and can slot up to 9 pieces of gear at a time. What gear you will carry and how you arrange it can unlock advantages that may make the difference between life and death.

Story Event System
You will encounter 40+ story events that will shape the story of your unique campaign. Your settlement's decisions and discoveries affect how the story events unfold. Story Events cover everything from setting up and fighting a monster to dramatic turning points in your settlements history. 
History.

The Knight is a Generic Hero Class resin miniature.

Store Description.
The Knight is the result of a collaboration between Adam & Lokman, exploring some well established tropes in fantasy art. Originally intended as a small line of Generic Hero Classes, the results were so compelling and un-generic, each hero's appearance told so many exciting stories that we wanted to integrate them into the KD world but so far nothing concrete has emerged.

This Knight's order casts their initiates out into the world. Their weapons, capable of cutting time and space, are used to sever the knights from their homes, sending them wandering through the world. So the knight must travel, performing enough good deeds to sufficiently convince her living weapon of the purity of her intention. Only then will she be allowed to return to join her anointed brother and sister knights.

Knowledges are techniques for showdown, hunt, and settlement phases. Unlike Fighting Arts, knowledges can evolve with careful observation from a hazy idea into a powerful weapon.

Survivors learn knowledges from their Philosphies and at the Forum settlement location in the arc settlement. Rules for each knowledge are found on its corresponding knowledge card. Knowledge cards can be gained from the knowledge deck, the Forum, or added from the game box.

Knowledge Cards.
Knowledge cards have the rules for performing them, and observation conditions that describe how the knowledge might evolve. Not all knowledge evolves.

Name and Level: The name and level of the knowledge (indicated by a roman numeral).
Lumi Cost: Knowledge can be gained at the Forum settlement location for a lumi cost.
Keywords: Knowledge cards have keywords that indicate information about the knowledge.
Card Art: Unique, evocative art.
Rules: Rules for performing the knowledge.
Observation Condition: Knowledge can improve with mindful practice. The observation conditions describes what must occur to make an observation.
Observations: Boxes indicate how many times survivors must make an observation before a knowledge can level up.
Level Up: When a survivor completes all observations, the knowledge levels up in one of three ways.

Advance. Refinement reached with practice. Survivors replace the knowledge with the higher level version of the same knowledge. Erase the old knowledge and record the new one in its place. The old knowledge becomes obsolete.

Epiphany. A novel discovery. The survivor gains a new knowledge that does not replace the old knowledge. It is possible for a survivor to replace the knowledge that gave birth to the epiphany if all their knowledge slots are full. However, the old knowledge remains in the settlement's knowledge deck.

Dangerous Observation. The consequences of hubris. Follow the rules listed here at the bottom of the card.

Recording Knowledge.
When a survivor gains a knowledge, they record its name (including its level, if it has one), rules, observation condition, and the number of observation boxes on their arc survivor record sheet.

Arc survivors have three knowledge slots: one slot for their tenet knowledge and two slots for any other knowledges.

Using Knowledge.
Survivors most often use their knowledge during showdowns. The rules on knowledges describe how and when to use them and any existing limits.

Knowledge with a Theory.
Some knowledge begins as an inkling of an idea too hazy to have an effect. Survivors must make enough observations to replace this knowledge with the next rank to benefit from their careful observations.

Knowledge with Attributes.
Some knowledges give survivors positive or negative attributes. Apply these effects to the survivor's attributes as long as they possess the knowledge. When this knowledge is removed or cannot be used, the attribute modifier no longer applies.

Knowledge Deck.
The knowledge deck grows and shrinks as survivors obtain dizzying new heights of enlightenment.

Starting Knowledge Deck.
During the prologue, you will build your initial Knowledge deck of four knowledge cards with the starting keyword.

The Gambler's Chest Expansion contains four starting knowledge cards: Darkness I, Despair I, Fear I, Hunger I.

Gaining Knowledge.
For arc survivors, the consequences of gaining knowledge are profound. They are uniquely capable of transmitting and preserving knowledge. When one survivor makes strides, the whole settlement benefits. These benefits endure beyond the lifetime of the survivor who uncovers them.

When a survivor gains knowledge, (e.g., Tenets, through their philosophy, as a result of observation at the Forum, etc.), they gain the highest level of that knowledge known in the settlement.

Check the Knowledge section of the arc settlement record sheet to confirm the highest level of this knowledge. The Knowledge section represents the sum of what is known in the settlement. If the survivor gained new knowledge from an observation or in game event, the whole settlement benefits from their discovery.

New Knowledge.
If the knowledge gained is new to the settlement, record it in the appropriate place on the arc survivor record sheet. Also add its name and level to the Knowledge section on the arc settlement record sheet. Finally, add the card to the knowledge deck.

Existing Knowledge.
When a survivor gains knowledge that is already known in the settlement, they gain the highest level any survivor has ever known. Check the Knowledge section of the campaign's Arc Settlement record sheet.

If a survivor gains a knowledge that has a higher level than the knowledge of the same name known in the settlement, the lower level is now obsolete. The higher level knowledge card replaces the obsolete knowledge in the knowledge deck, archive the obsolete knowledge. Update the Knowledge section to reflect this progress.

If the survivor gained knowledge that is a lower level than what is already known in the settlement, they benefit from others' experience. They gain the highest level of that knowledge known in the settlement. Do not add the lower level knowledge back into the knowledge deck.

For example, Lucy advances Tenacity I to Tenacity II. However, Tenacity III is already known in the settlement. Lucy gains Tenacity III instead.

If the survivor gained knowledge that is the same level as one they already know, nothing happens.

Random Knowledge.
When survivors gain random knowledge, shuffle the knowledge deck, and draw from the top.

Full Knowledge Slots.
If a survivor has 3 knowledges and gains a new one, they may choose to replace any but their tenet knowledge. If they gained the knowledge by advancing to the next level they must gain it. Erase the knowledge and record the new one.

Tenet Knowledge.
While a survivor has their philosophy, the philosophy's tenet knowledge is permanent and cannot be lost or removed for any reason. For everyone else in the settlement, this survivor's tenet knowledge is the same as other knowledges. It is in the knowledge deck unless it is obsolete.

It is possible for a survivor to already have the knowledge that becomes their tenet knowledge. When this happens, simply move all of its information (including observations) into the tenet knowledge slot.

Gaining Fighting Arts.
Fighting arts are impulses that arc survivors do not have. Attempting to learn them puts their minds under immense stress. When fighting arts would be gained, arc survivors Vaultless instead. Through this story arc survivors may gain fighting arts.

Arc survivors can possess one fighting art and one secret fighting art.

Losing Access to Knowledge.
If arc survivors cannot use their fighting arts they also cannot use their knowledge (e.g., when an arc survivor suffers the Ruptured Muscle permanent injury). If they cannot use knowledges they cannot accumulate observations. This includes tenet knowledges. However, arc survivors are always beholden to their neurosis.

Knowledge Levels Up.
Careful observation of experience accumulates until enough is gathered and knowledge evolves.

Players should keep their knowledges' observation conditions in mind. When they occur, fill the corresponding observation box on the arc survivor record sheet. When the last box is filled, the knowledge levels up. You must level up a knowledge when its observations are full. Immediately gain the benefits of leveling up listed on the knowledge card.

In the chaos of existence, survivors may miss an opportunity for observation. Unless an observation is recorded at the moment it takes place, it is gone like so much ephemera. If a dangerous observation is missed, record it when you realize you missed it.

Knowledge at the Forum.
After unlocking the Forum collective cognition milestone, survivors gather there to share knowledge. In the excited bustle of conversation and demonstration, ideas can be shared!

Arc Survivors Share Knowledge.
During the setup of the settlement phase, shuffle the knowledge deck and draw three cards, placing them next to the Forum settlement location. These are the knowledges shared by survivors this lantern year.

During the Develop step, a survivor can select a knowledge card, pay its lumi cost, and gain it. Once gained, move the knowledge from the Forum back to the knowledge deck.

Survivors may spend lumi at the Forum to add more knowledge cards to the Forum.

As the collective cognition of the settlement improves, it unlocks other benefits of vigorous discourse.

In the spirit of collective cooperation, the lumi cost of some activities at the Forum can be paid by more than one survivor. Survivors may combine their lumi to jointly pay the cost of these activities.

Lantern Mites is a Crimson Crocodile hunt event card introduced in the Gambler's Chest Expansion.

Lantern Mites.
The survivors rest under the glow of a lantern glowing from a fleshy stalk. Each survivor gains +1 survival.

One after another, they start to feel their hair moving at the roots. Small hard-to-see insects burrow into their scalps, laying eggs! Each survivor rolls 1d10.

The survivor with the highest result eats all the lantern mites off their body. They gain +1 survival.

The survivor with the lowest result gains the Terrified survivor status card. They cannot remove it until the showdown ends for any reason.

Everyone else gains +2 insanity.

Lanternism is a Tier 1 Philosophy in the Gambler's Chest Expansion.

The Dead Light the Way.
Photaxis: You are bound by the light. While there is a Fallen Lantern terrain tile on the board, you cannot spend survival.

Rank 1 - Luminous Bodies.

Lanterns extinguish with the passing of life. If you updated your death count this lantern year, gain a death token the next time you depart.

Rank 2 - The Undying Light.
Gain +1 lumi and roll 1d10.

CC 25 - Introspection.
Your world is lit by the monuments of the dead. Gain the Graves principle. If you have it already and you have Light Eater, you realize you are living in a buffet. Your settlement also gains the Cannibalize principle.

Rank 3 - What's Inside.
Gain +1 lumi and roll 1d10.

CC 4 - Introspection.
You await the appearance of a lantern once clutched tightly for survival. You can feel the fleeting strength of its former bearer as you carry it out of the settlement. If you updated your death count this lantern year, gain a death token the next time you depart.

Rank 4 - Overseer.
Gain +1 lumi. Compare which is greater: the current death count or the lantern year. Act accordingly.

Death Count - Waning.
Gain endeavor. Gain additional endeavors equal to the increase of your Death Count this lantern year.

Lantern Year - Waxing.
Gain Ghostzerker.

They Are Equal - Syzygy.
Gain four permanent affinities of your choice.

The Last Bard is a limited release resin miniature.

Store Description.
The Last Bard heard the beat of the land pulsing in her ears. She fashioned the delicate, resonant legs of the Discord Cricket into a headpiece to deafen her to all but the drumming heartbeat of the world. To that beat she taught the Frogdogs their forlorn song and composed the lullaby the Nightmare Ram bleats to the children it will never meet. She performed her breathtaking first symphony on the straining neck of her living instrument, choking the life from all bards who ever were - or ever would be. Now she gathers inspiration for her magnum opus, a march stirring enough to move the gods.

Limited Releases encompass any models that are released outside of the Kingdom Death: Monster content. Limited Releases can be released as hand-cast resin models, holiday-themed plastic kits, 3D printed miniatures or special miniature bundles. These kits are often only available to be purchased when they are released on the store, and unavailable otherwise. 

Three terms are often used for limited releases: "First Run", "Encore", and "Deathgrey". First Run refers to the original batch of a resin figure, and they include a numbered certificate of authenticity, while Encore refers to a miniature that has been reprinted. Encores include all of the contents found within a First Run, barring the certificate of authenticity. Deathgrey refers to a limited 3D printed photoresin model. Deathgrey editions are often printed in smaller batches than their orange photoresin counterparts.

Store Description.
Three brother generals command the vast armies of the Golden Entities domain. Each imbued with a different temperament and a strong will of their own. The middle brother is the most attached to the human industry and artistry. He cultivates a courtly civilized appearance and graceful swordsmanship, surrounding himself with human thralls allowing them to enjoy their short tragic existence in his awesome presence.
Limited Release Description

The Lion Knight is the most human of the Golden Entities creations and is forever obsessed with truly understanding man.

Ash, Ryan and Sam are scholars raised and educated from the Lion Knight's private museums. They share a life of luxury and discovery, often travelling with the Lion Knight on grand art collecting expeditions. Their unique life makes them some of the most knowledgeable women in all of Kingdom Death. Granting them domain over even some White Speaker stories including the secret of ageing, giving them eternally healthy and youthful bodies.
Kickstarter 1.0 Update 27

Incapable of emotion, the Lion Knight seeks to understand the world around it through its bizarre, self-serving stage productions. Between performances, it is a distant husk, unaffected by the normal world. When the time comes, "actors" are gathered by the Lion Knight's masked retinue to join it onstage. There, it hopes to capture and vicariously experience their excitement, fears, and ultimately, their deaths. However, it remains up to the survivors to decide whether or not they stick to their scripts.
Expansion Release Description

The Mage is a Generic Hero Class resin miniature.

Store Description.
The Mage is the 3rd result of a collaboration between Adam & Lokman, exploring some well established tropes in fantasy art. Originally intended as a small line of Generic Hero Classes, the results were so compelling and un-generic, each hero's appearance told so many exciting stories that we wanted to integrate them into the KD world but so far nothing concrete has emerged.

Perhaps...

the Mage comes from settlement of Aromachologists. Their magic, distilled oils from a variety of eccentric entities. Maybe, the settlement met a terrible fate, the raw oil from the Vermillion Raven reducing the population to mere doll like husks. And it may be the Mage escaped with a fistful of her kin and the twisted will to burn them for power to ensure her continued prosperity.

Murder is an arc settlement event in the Gambler's Chest Expansion. It replaces the Murder settlement event from the core game in arc settlement campaigns.

Murder.
The settlement discovers someone is missing. The survivor with the highest Hunt XP disappeared while the settlement slept. They are dead. Do not gain the benefits of your death principle. Nominate the survivor with the highest insanity to be the killer. They mask their glee as the victim's corpse is finally discovered decomposing at the edge of the settlement.

Add the Homicidalism Systemic philosophy card to your philosophy deck if it does not already contain it.

If the killer does not already have Marrowism, they immediately adopt Homicidalism. Replace their current philosophy, tenet, and neurosis.

Lingering Effects.
A pall of fear and suspicion hangs over the settlement, stifling open discourse.

It costs an additional lumi to learn knowledges at the Forum this lantern year.

These figures inhabit the far future of the Kingdom Death story, which is still deeply shrouded in mystery. Collectors and hobbyists interested in getting their hands on these miniatures before they make their debut in Kingdom Death games can grab them naked now.

The Necromancer Boss is a Limited Release resin miniature.

Store Description.
For his indiscriminating lust for knowledge, his own people cast him off the side of the Glittering Mountains. However, giants of the Glittering Mountain are nearly indestructible save for a peppercorn sized weakness on their body. For years, the giant lay at the base of the mountain moaning as his wounds mended, cursing his folk, and vowing revenge.

The giant turned to the dark arts seeking power. His massive brain quickly absorbed what other scholars spent years mastering. Overtaking his teachers, he built the Black Citadel, charging students exorbitant fees to study by his side. With his massive wealth and army of the dead he finally laid waste to the giants of the Glittering Mountains.

Wary of a human apprentice, the Necromancer Boss cast a powerful love curse on him. Madly in love, the appetence's focus waned and his power too. When the apprentice's beloved perished, the apprentice gave his body to resurrect her. The Necromancer Boss knows that when his apprentice is returned, he will face retribution. 

Contents.
1 x Resin Necromancer Boss
Large matte print of the original concept artwork on heavy card stock
Character art card

Notes.
Unlike most miniatures, the Necromancer Boss does not come with a base because the bottom of it is flat enough to stand upright. However, given its size, a 50mm base would be appropriate.

Despite having lore associated with the Necromancer Generic Hero Class, the Necromancer Boss itself is not a Generic miniature, as indicated by the store page, art card, and box it is sold in.

The Novice is a Generic Hero Class resin miniature.

Store Description.
The Novice is the result of a collaboration between Adam & Lokman, exploring some well established tropes in fantasy art. Originally intended as a small line of Generic Hero Classes, the results were so compelling and un-generic, each hero's appearance told so many exciting stories that we wanted to integrate them into the KD world but so far nothing concrete has emerged.

On the eve of the Novice Festival, the uninitiated youth are carted away through dizzying routes and dropped deep into the infested forests. There, the initiates must join forces to rise to the challenge of returning home, or face a grisly demise in the unknown woods. Sweat and blood drip onto the forest floor from the cheeks of the scrambling novices eager to complete their initiation. All the while, gloomy trees feast on the vigorous fluids of youth, erupting in the crimson blossoms that mark the day of initiation.

The Pariah is the last male white speaker. He violated the vows of the white speaker cult by murdering countless white speakers, unravelling the quivering lobes of their brains, to piece together a forbidden story hidden in the cult's members.

The Phoenix is a chaotic quarry to hunt, and isn't an easy quarry to repeat hunt due to some of the hunt mechanics, as well as the experience mechanics which the Phoenix toys with. It is probable to have a survivor significantly changed during the hunt, or even outright die before they reach the showdown. 

Hunt Events.
The Phoenix has three categories of hunt events: Ones that do moderate negative effects, ones that shift the Phoenix or the survivors forward or backward on the hunt board, and chaotic ones which can do wildly positive or negative things to the survivor depending on their role within your settlement.

The hunt also features the Straggler mechanic of each survivor rolling 1d10 and the lowest being affected in some way.

Things which you may experience on a Phoenix Hunt:
Ambush
Major survivor and quarry movement forward and back
Major brain damage
Minor understanding
Major damage
Major hunt XP gain and loss
Unexpected overwhelming darkness
Gear loss
Minor additional resources

Chaos.
There are a number of events during the hunt and showdown with the Phoenix which can mess with a survivor in ways that no other quarry will.

There are examples where survivors will be effectively reborn, losing all XP and bonuses, but also losing all negative things as well. There are also minor versions of these, including only limbs being rebirthed.

The fact that much of this is uncontrollable does mean that there is a heavier amount of luck involved with a Phoenix hunt compared to other quarries.

Good gear for Phoenix hunters.
The following items have additional value during a Phoenix hunt are listed below:

Pinups are a sexy and fun take on characters found in the world of Kingdom Death. Anything linked to by this page should be considered NSFW, and may not have additional warnings.

List of Pinup Miniatures.
Neko Twilight Knight
Other Miniatures.
These miniatures are not categorized as Pinup miniatures, but have a heavy amount of nudity, and should be considered NSFW.

Lore.
The aptly named Plain of Faces is named after the fact that the very ground of this area is made up of stone faces. The Plain of Faces is the domain of The Scribe, and his words seem to have an effect on the reality of this area. There is likely a tie between The Scribe's works, and the survivors who awaken on the plains, rubbing ink from their eyes. The Plain of Faces sees an indeterminate amount of human settlements arise, scratching and scraping for survival. The King's Men and The Hand occasionally pay visits to these settlements as brutal harbingers of The King's approach.Kingdom Death shop descriptions, Recorded on VibrantLantern.com

Gameplay.
The Plain of Faces is the setting for most of the campaigns in the Kingdom Death: Monster boardgame.

Store Description.
Saviors are undaunted heroes, single minded and suicidally reckless in their quest to make a change in mankind's horrible existence. In their dreams Saviors visit the domain of the Ethereal Dreamer which grants them wondrous knowledge at a startling price. Tapping greater power causes their bodies to age rapidly. As they delve deeper into the collective dream they leave more of themselves behind. Mighty Saviors will grow frail and appear faded at their edges, vanishing slowly at the height of their power.

The Savior (Female) is a limited release resin miniature.

Store Description.
Saviors are undaunted heroes, single minded and suicidally reckless in their quest to make a change in mankind's horrible existence. This meteoric existence ensures their lifespan will be short but bright.

Burning Brightest
The Saviors unwavering guiding star is a shared destiny to change the world for the better. Their eyes constantly open to the tormented existence of others, they dedicate the whole of their being to others. Each act of heroism intoxicates the Saviors, delirious from the heady realization of their higher purpose they are emboldened to greater risks to their own safety. Saviors seek to symbolize hope in a dark and drab world, often adopting bright bizarre garb to match their stations as self-appointed heroes of mankind.
Dreamers with Blackened Feet
In their dreams Saviors travel to an entity they call the Ethereal Dreamer. Nightly, they trudge through the twisting scape of the world's collective nightmares seeking the Dreamer's secrets of power and magic. Over time their dream pilgrimage leaves the Savior threadbare; their feet become sooty and gnarled , their faces sallow with deep shadows under their eyes. Saviors who exceed their expected lifespan eventually begin to fade bit by bit, devoured by the dream world that once empowered them.

Contents.
1 x Resin Savior Miniature
1 x Kingdom Death 30mm Base
6" x 4" Print of the Original Concept Artwork on heavy card stock.
