The scout gear grid is a special gear grid introduced in the Gambler's Chest Expansion. It can be used in addition to the normal four gear grids for departing survivors.

The scout gear grid has only four spaces for gear cards. Most of the grid space is taken up by the Dreaded Pack, which is printed on the grid in addition to Fist & Tooth.

The scout gear grid does not reiterate the Showdown rules printed on the other gear grids. Instead, it reiterates the following rules for the scout.

The Scout.
When survivors depart, you may nominate a survivor to wear the Dreaded Pack. They must use this gear grid and depart as the scout for this lantern year. A survivor with Cursed gear may not depart as the scout.

The scout gear grid is the only one that may have gear with the scout keyword.

Dreaded Pack.
item, scout, stinky, heavy

-2 movement

If you are alone during the hunt or at the start of your act during the showdown, you may enact the Death Pact (Logistics of Death). You awaken the Dreaded Pack with its small bell. A blinding stench erupts.

In past campaigns, the gruesome machinations of the world worked in the survivors' favor. Even if the hunting survivors were lost, their gear was inexorably returned to the settlement, carried by strange creatures that herald the survivors' demise.

The scout is an optional component that can be added to any campaign. Playing with scouts expands the simulation of survivors leaving the settlement without the security of their gear automatically returning.

If a scout is not present when the hunting survivors perish, all of the survivors' gear and resources are lost.

If a scout accompanied the hunting survivors when they perished, the scout must perform their grim duty and attempt to drag the settlement's valuables home.

Adding Scouts.
To add scouts to a campaign, add Extinguished Guidepost to lantern year 1 of the timeline on your settlement record sheet. Replace the Pictograph innovation with Pictograph (Scout). Do not add Lamplighter to the settlement event deck until explicitly instructed.

Current Campaign.
The scout introduces significant changes to your settlement and gameplay. It is not recommended as a mid-campaign addition.

People of the Dream Keeper Uses Scouts.
The scout's introductory story event is already printed on the settlement record sheet timeline.

Scout Components.
In the somber wake of the prologue, the survivors know that monsters are relentless. Gathered at the extinguished guidepost, they make a promise. If they seek foes in the darkness, they must triumph or not return at all. Otherwise, monsters will follow the survivors back to decimate the settlement.

Death Pact.
The Death Pact innovation represents this promise. When the survivors are defeated or lost on the hunt, perform Logistics of Death, which describes what happens to the scout and the settlement's belongings.

Pictograph.
The settlement can special innovate Pictograph (Scout) after they gain the Death Pact innovation. Using a symbology of their own making, the scout deepens the settlement's understanding of their most powerful foes.

Scout Hunt Events.
When the settlement gains their first scout, their hunts change. The scout hunt event card replaces a basic hunt event card. When the card is revealed during the hunt, the survivors confront new hunt events found in the Scout Hunt Event table.

Outskirts.
A darkened lantern halberd juts from the ground at the settlement's edge. In its gloomy shadow, the scout makes their preparations at the outskirts of the settlement. The Outskirts settlement location is gained during Extinguished Guidepost.

At the Outskirts, the settlement can craft scout gear that can be carried only in the scout's gear grid. The settlement can also endeavor to collect Hollow Stone strange resources.

Scout Gear Grid.
The scout carries a dread stinking roll so repulsive, the teeming darkness avoids it. When the scout finds themselves alone, they may use it to travel in questionable safety.

The scout uses a corresponding gear grid with only four free spaces; the remaining space is occupied by the burdensome Dreaded Pack.

Scout Keyword & Gear.
The scout's gear grid is the only gear grid that may hold gear with the scout keyword. The scout gear grid may include any gear that is not Cursed, because the Dreaded Pack cannot abide a Cursed presence. If the scout gains Cursed gear during the hunt or the showdown, they may never again depart as a scout.

Hunting with a Scout.
When survivors depart, they may nominate a survivor to wear the Dreaded Pack. This survivor is the scout for that lantern year. The scout departs alongside up to four hunting survivors and gains all departing survivor bonuses.

This often means that five survivors depart, rather than four. If the scout survives to return to the settlement, they contribute endeavors as normal, even if they are the only one alive.

Hunt Phase.
The scout is part of the hunting party. They participate in and reveal hunt events just like other survivors. When an event affects all survivors, it affects the scout as well. The hunt event revealer takes charge of the scout.

Showdowns with a Scout.
The scout is a survivor and participates in showdowns and encounters just like everyone else. They gain Arrival bonuses, gain Movement and Activation each act, and participate in the Aftermath.

The scout is placed last during Showdown/Encounter Setup. If there are no spaces remaining as indicated by Showdown Setup, place the scout in the closest unoccupied space to another survivor.

Each round, the monster controller takes charge of the scout. The scout is not any player's survivor and does not gain insanity bonuses when targeted by the monster controller.

Hiding During the Showdown.
The Stone Face Cloak is scout gear that allows the scout to hide during the showdown. The scout's model is replaced by the Hidden Face terrain tile, which represents its camouflaged form. Its model waits on the corresponding terrain card.

While off the showdown board, scouts cannot be targeted by the monster or suffer effects that the monster performs on all survivors. The terrain card shows how to return to the board.

If another game rule prevents the scout from placing the Hidden Face terrain tile, they cannot hide.

The Scout's Dreaded Choice.
If all other survivors perish, the scout has a choice: continue to fight, or end the showdown in Defeat and trigger Logistics of Death.

Logistics of Death.
If the hunting survivors perish during the hunt or are defeated in the showdown, the settlement's death pact triggers Logistics of Death.

Before resolving Logistics of Death, resolve any hunt event outcomes and showdown defeat conditions.

Logistics of Death describes the morbid procedure the scout endures to return the settlement's belongings. There are different procedures if the survivors perished chasing a quarry than if facing a nemesis.

The Recovery Team describes the outcomes of defeat after a nemesis showdown at the settlement's edge. By keenly observing the carnage, the scout may mitigate the devastation left by a rampaging nemesis.

The Long Journey Home describes what happens when the survivors perish on the hunt or in a showdown with a quarry monster, depending on whether the scout survives.

If the scout dies along with the hunting survivors, the settlement's prospects are dire. Everything is Lost to the Darkness.

If the scout dies during the hunt or showdown but the showdown ends in Victory, the Dreaded Pack and the scout's gear are carried home by the remaining victorious survivors.

The Dreaded Pack Is Lost.
If the scout and their gear are Lost to the Darkness during Logistics of Death, the settlement is in peril. Without the Dreaded Pack, the settlement cannot nominate a scout, recover the hunting party's belongings, or gain any other scouts benefits. A rare confluence of fortune may add another Dreaded Pack to the settlement, but it is unlikely.

Scout Discoveries.
Scouts bear witness to the hunting survivors' triumphs. In the wake of difficult victories, the scout explores the battlefield with fresh eyes.

After the settlement innovates Pictograph, they may gain Scout Discoveries. The first time the survivors defeat a lvl 3+ quarry monster with a surviving scout, the scout gains that monster's Scout Discovery.

Resolve the victory conditions of the Aftermath, then the scout resolves the Scout Discovery.

If no Scout Discovery card exists for the defeated monster do not gain one.

Monster Tablet.
Each Scout Discovery enables the scout to create a corresponding monster tablet gear. Scouts commit their in-depth insights in scout shorthand onto wearisome slabs. Then, the scout uses them to coach the hunting survivors.

Each tablet describes a useful maneuver that works only against that tablet's respective monster. The scout must be alive and carrying the tablet corresponding to the quarry at hand to use its effects.

The Antelope is quite a skittish quarry, and begins to introduce a few dangerous mechanics, making it a more niche hunting target. It is a good source of Fresh Acanthus, as well as additional resources if critical hits can be utilized. 

Hunt Events.
The hunt events for the Screaming Antelope for the most part are similar to the White Lion's in terms of danger level, but a few hunt events can ramp up the difficulty significantly, so can provide an additional level of risk to hunt.

Things which you may experience on an antelope hunt:
Minor brain damage
Minor event damage
Minor strength loss
Minor additional resources
Minor skipping forward hunt spaces
Major Healing
Minor chance of Fresh Acanthus
Major quarry moving away hunt spaces

Migration and friends.
Migration and a few other hunt events form a family of events which can make a hunt much more difficult than expected. Migration moves the quarry 3 squares further away from the survivors, but there are other events which cause 1 square movements. This can be beneficial for some groups as they can explore more hunt events, but for newer hunts it can be lethal. Forcing Overwhelming Darkness on survivors when not expected is an easy way to stop a hunt,

Dead Antelope.
Sometimes you are not the only thing hunting the Screaming Antelope. If a White Lion kills the antelope before you do, then you will be forced into a powered up Lion fight which nets you antelope resources from the carrion in addition to the lion. It's a situation which can be accounted for and even be used as a strategy, but can ruin some hunting groups.

The Showdown.
The Antelope has a similar macro strategy than the Lion, but some different specifics. The Antelope is a very mobile target, often making attacks and then making a second move away from survivors, which makes it quite difficult to lay in a good round of four hunters outputting heavy damage.

The fight starts in a patch of Acanthus plants, which are relevant for both foraging, as well as being a significant source of healing for the Antelope. The Antelope can heal 1d5 wounds from eating a single plant, which is quite a large setback if a 4 or 5 is rolled.

The antelope also has a number of ways to mess with survivors' weapons. It has a number of Super-Dense locations, breaking bone gear. In addition, the beast has some situations which can have weapons knocked out of hand, or even grabbed by the large undermouth. Extra weapons are recommended to compensate.

It does have a weakness though. A large number of hit locations have -2 toughness on locations wounded with a Shield or Club type weapon. This is quite a consistent experience, so packing weapons of this type can help punch through damage

In summary, some good things to remember during the showdown are:
The blind spot can get targeted by powerful kicks
Harvesting Acanthus to prevent healing can be utilized
Use Shields or Clubs for +2 to wound
Cardinal Directions can be a deathtrap as the antelope gets bonus damage when trampling
Be aware of weapons being knocked away or eaten
Bone weapons can break with some regularity
Dash will allow you to keep up with the very mobile quarry

Lore.
The Silver City is an ancient lost city, buried deep under the earth. After the decline of the city, its previous ruler took a strange parasite into his body, warping and twisting him into the Lion God. The Lion God now stalks the abandoned streets of his city, taking out his rage on any crossing his path.

Survivors who stumble across the Silver City can plumb its depths for artifacts of power. Although, like any good artifact of power, almost all of them tend to be cursed!Lion God Expansion Rulebook

Gameplay.
The Silver City can be visited during the Showdown with the Lion God. As the fight rages on, there's a possibility for sinkholes to open up in the hollow earth. Survivors can explore down into the sinkhole, uncovering different ruins of the Silver City. If lucky they will escape with valuable items.

In the Kingdom Death: Monster 1.5 Kickstarter, the Silver City expansion was announced. This expansion will require the original Lion God expansion, adding a dungeon exploration mechanic in lieu of hunting a quarry. Kingdom Death: Monster 1.5 Update Kickstarter, Update #34

The Strider Princess is a Generic Hero Class resin miniature.

Store Description.
The Strider Princess continues the result of a collaboration between Adam & Lokman, exploring some well established tropes in fantasy art. Originally intended as a small line of Generic Hero Classes, the results were so compelling and un-generic, each hero's appearance told so many exciting stories that we wanted to integrate them into the KD world but so far nothing concrete has emerged. 

Once a suitor proffered a dying sylph at the Princess’s feet. Its radiant hair fell over her royal slippers as she watched the last moments of its sparkling form. The Princess’s heart shattered with grief and she fell into a righteous rage. She slaughtered her suitor with a ceremonial dagger and escaped into the wilds with the weightless corpse in tow. She strung a bow with the sylph’s vivid hair and fletched her arrows with its iridescent wings. Her bow fired true with the impossible accuracy of her vengeance. Now as the Strider Princess, she is a notorious danger found among the lairs of rare creatures. Haunting the world, cutting down those that would threaten the delicate and beautiful.

Infant Sunstalkers spend their days alongside their squirming siblings, collectively doted on by their tiny human nursemaids. Endlessly they slurp and regurgitate the mineral-rich fluids of the sacred pool, oily waters that are nothing less than the nutrient-infused vomit of their aloof, sky-bound parent. Occasionally, one of their guardians approaches with their own babbling offspring. Weighing it with specialized limbs, aInfant Sunstalker judges whether it’s merely a writhing morsel or if it’s fit for something more.

Hunted as prey, herded and domesticated as draft animals, humans occupy a low rung on the food chain of Kingdom Deaths many strange ecosystems. Tasting Notes are a community-driven endeavor where rules questions are submitted to Tastemaker and Team Death through the Lantern's Reign discord. These questions are answered by the team on their free time, and on occasion are added to the official FAQ.

Tasting Notes should be considered semi-official rulings to rules questions and always have the following caveat: "Please note that these answers apply to the current live version of Kingdom Death: Monster. Subsequent releases may introduce new rules or change existing products in a way that affects the following clarifications or renders them irrelevant."

NOTE: These questions and answers include responses for content from the Gambler's Chest Expansion, so may include information that could be considered a spoiler.

Questions and Answers.

Q: What node is the White Gigalion? Do you gain CC from fighting it separately from a White Lion?.
A: The White Gigalion is a node 1 monster. It is not treated as a separate entity from the White Lion for purposes of CC.

Q: One of the roll results upon choosing "Collective Toil" during "Principle: Society" states that survivors should gain 2 random White Lion resources. Should this be treated as 2 random Node 1 resources in campaigns that do not include the White Lion?.
A: Gain 2 random White Lion resources as instructed. These are Node 1 monster resources. However, do note that you will likely not have access to the Catarium or other settlement locations/gear recipe sources that require specific White Lion resources if your campaign does not include the White Lion.

Q: Does the clause "before you make a wound attempt/before making a wound attempt..." (Blood Compass Lantern, Rawhide Bandana, etc.) mean "before making any wound attempts in an attack" or "before making a wound attempt (on a chosen hit location)"?.
A: The latter. This means that an effect that occurs "before making a wound attempt" in an attack with multiple hit locations can occur before making a wound attempt against any of these hit locations.

Q: The 1-3 roll result of Gorm Climate instructs players to dismantle an innovation, returning it to the innovation deck. What types of innovations can be chosen to be returned to the innovation deck? Does dismantling an innovation count as archiving it?.
A: All innovations that the settlement has access to are applicable to be dismantled. When an innovation is returned to the innovation deck, the settlement loses access to the effects associated with that innovation until it is gained again from the innovation deck. Dismantling an innovation is not archiving it.

Q: If a weapon mastery is dismantled by Gorm Climate while there is no associated master in the settlement, is it placed in the innovation deck, or returned to the weapon proficiency deck?.
A: It is returned to the weapon proficiency deck.

Q: Can a gear with arrows in the Second Stomach survivor status card point to another piece of gear in your gear grid? Can a piece of gear in the Second Stomach survivor status card be pointed to by a piece of gear with arrows in your gear grid? Can a gear in the Second Stomach survivor status card with affinity halves connect with another piece of gear in your gear grid with affinity halves?.
A: No, no, and no. However, gear in the Second Stomach survivor status card are still treated as being in your gear grid for the purposes of affinity bonuses, so a gear with an affinity bonus in the Second Stomach survivor status card can still gain its affinity bonus effect if you have the prerequisite affinities completed in the rest of your gear grid.

Q: The Dark Impulse 3 knowledge allows a survivor to gain all of the positive attributes of another survivor they kill. What exactly does this entail?.
A: Dark Impulse 3 allows a survivor to gain the permanent positive attributes (from baseline) of another survivor they kill. For example, a survivor with Dark Impulse 3 kills another survivor with 6 movement, 1 strength, and -1 accuracy. The first survivor gains +1 movement (as the killed survivor had +1 movement from their baseline of 5), +1 strength, and no accuracy (as Dark Impulse only grants positive attributes). Unless otherwise qualified with a timing (e.g.- "until end of the attack"), attributes described in philosophies and their corresponding knowledge cards refer to "permanent attributes" (Gambler's Chest Rulebook pg. 69). This means that Dark Impulse 3 does account for Attribute Modifier Token attribute tokens or other temporary attribute bonuses. Systemic Pressure and Torment are survivor attributes and can be granted by Dark Impulse 3. Lumi, while a survivor trait like survival or insanity, is not a survivor attribute. (Gambler's Chest Rulebook pg. 67).

Q: Placing 3 knowledge cards face up next to the Forum (Share) normally occurs during the settlement phase setup once the settlement gains access to the Forum settlement location. Do you place these 3 knowledge cards the first time the Forum settlement location is gained, considering it is gained after settlement phase setup?.
A: No.

Q: (Arc) Intimacy grants bonuses if you "earned [at least X] CC this year". However, CC is recorded during the Aftermath. Does this mean that you only gain the bonuses for (Arc) Intimacy if you gained the requisite amount of CC during the current lantern year?.
A: Collective Cognition is recorded during the Aftermath (specifically, after the Aftermath has been resolved) in order to minimize the chances of players forgetting to update their Collective Cognition. The intent behind the (Arc) Intimacy bonuses is to check if your Collective Cognition has increased in the current lantern year's settlement phase in comparison to the last lantern year's settlement phase (the full phrase of which could not fully fit within the confines of the story event).

Q: Should Skull and Handed Skull have the skull keyword?.
A: Skull should have the skull keyword. Handed Skull is too large to be used as an analogous material in crafting recipes that require skull resources to have the skull keyword.

Q: When a survivor gains a nickname, would this qualify as "being named"? Can a survivor have a nickname and no name?.
A: No. Yes.

Q: How does the Dung Beetle Knight's Trap, Slam Dunk, work if the monster is not adjacent to the attacker after it full moves directly towards the attacker?.
A: If the monster is not adjacent to the attacker after it full moves directly towards the attacker, it with neither place the monster in any space adjacent to the Resin Dung Ball nor have the attacker suffer damage and gain the Smell World survivor status card.

Q: Are milestones considered events? Are they once per lifetime? The Milestone section in the rulebook never mentions milestones are once per lifetime. Some events that are triggered upon reaching a Milestone clarify that the specific event itself is once per lifetime..
A: A milestone is a set of circumstances that can be fulfilled (e.g.- having 16 Hunt XP, having 8 weapon proficiency levels, having 10 Death Count, etc.). Milestones are not events.

At baseline, milestones do not have rules associated with them. However, events may occur when specific milestones are reached. These events occur at the moment the specific milestone is reached. These events are generally known as Milestone Events (e.g.- Hooded Knight is a Milestone Story Event that occurs when a settlement has 5 innovations. If Hooded Knight is not an available Story Event within your campaign, nothing happens when your settlement reaches 5 innovations).

Q: Curse Conductor allows a survivor to gain the monster controller tile when they wound the monster with an arrow. Does this extend to the Death Die?.
A: No. Curse Conductor (and analogous effects such as Gloom Hammer) only allow survivors to gain the monster controller tile, and do not extend to effects that replace the monster controller tile, like the Death Die. If a survivor is instructed to gain the monster controller tile while it is not in play, nothing happens.

Q: Can the 1-2 and 7+ roll results of Baby and the Sword Hunt Event be rerolled?.
A: Yes. However, once players begin resolving the Harvester hunt event (Hunt Event 10), that particular event cannot be rerolled or avoided.

Q: Is it intended for the Baby and the Sword hunt event to only remove itself from the Hunt Event Deck on a roll result of 7+?.
A: Yes.

Q: When a survivor is suffering from an effect that lowers their total affinities of a color, how does this interact with an affinity bonus that requires puzzle affinities of that color? How does this interact with Prismatic?.
A: When a survivor is suffering from an effect that lowers their total affinities of a color, an affinity bonus that requires puzzle affinities of that color is only active if the requisite puzzle affinities are connected and the survivor has enough affinities of that color such that the survivor is able to activate the affinity bonus even after adjusting their total number of affinities. A survivor with an effect that lowers their total affinities of a color and Prismatic will decrease their total number of affinities by the appropriate amount, as complete affinities of Prismatic survivors count as all colors.

Q: How does Weapon Mastery innovation creation work? Innovations can be lost. Does this mean that, because this is not a triggered event, nor once per lifetime, that a Master will instantly recreate a lost Mastery Innovation? Is this the same for a survivor with 8 proficiency levels starting a new settlement in a new game+? They show up and instantly create the innovation in the new settlement? Do they need the ranks still filled in on the their survivor sheet? When a Master switches weapon proficiency types they still remain a master of that weapon type. Is this enough to recreate an innovation?.
A: A Weapon Mastery innovation is created when a survivor has the max amount of weapon proficiency levels on the corresponding weapon type. If a Weapon Mastery innovation is lost while a survivor still has the max amount of weapon proficiency levels, the Weapon Mastery innovation will be recreated. If a Weapon Mastery innovation is lost after the survivor that reached the max amount of weapon proficiency levels has changed their proficiency, the innovation will not be recreated.

Q: When a survivor reaches Mastery, they also become a “Master” of whatever weapon type they had selected at the time. Where on the survivor record sheet should this be written? Is this meant to be tracked? Is this considered an ability or something else?.
A: The survivor who achieved Mastery should be tracked, Players may record this information in that survivor's record sheet or the settlement's record sheet. This is not considered a survivor ability.

Q: If a Shield Master has the Shielderang fighting art and decides to switch weapon proficiencies, will they still be considered to have 8 levels of Shield weapon proficiency?.
A: No.

Q: What happens when an insane survivor is adjacent to two other survivors with Boss Mehndi in their gear grids?.
A: The insane survivor would gain +2 speed while adjacent to the two other survivors.

Q: Can survivors that become the starting survivors for a new settlement via Clinging Mists start a settlement that belongs to a different campaign from the settlement they were originally from?.
A: Yes. Note that this may cause slight discrepancies or issues in regards to game rules. Where issues arise, players should determine as a group how they would like to resolve the issue, ruling against the survivors' favor when possible.

Q: Can a survivor originally from a People of the Sun settlement with access to the Embolden and Overcharge survival actions utilize these survival actions after becoming a starting survivor for a different settlement?.
A: No. In this instance, the survivor's ability to utilize the Embolden and Overcharge survival actions arose from settlement-specific innovations that do not exist within their new settlement. Similarly, the survivor's survival limit is determined by the survival limit of their new settlement and not the last known survival limit of their previous settlement.

Q: Do damage modifiers (e.g.- +1 damage tokens, +1 damage due the monster level) increase the damage of attack profiles that have "-" listed as their damage?.
A: No.

Q: Extreme Heat says survivors may not wear heavy gear. When a survivor is prevented from wearing a gear type, they are unable to place that type of gear in their gear grid. How would you gain the White Sunlion Hybrid Armor set bonus to ignore this if you cannot wear it to begin with?.
A: A survivor may elect to claim the White Sunlion Hybrid Armor set bonus by placing all of the appropriate gear pieces in their gear grid. If all the pieces of gear associated with the White Sunlion Hybrid Armor Set have been placed on the gear grid and the Sunlion Hybrid Armor set bonus is active for the survivor, the effect of the set bonus to ignore Extreme Heat is applicable, allowing the survivor to wear the appropriate gear pieces. If this is not the case, the survivor must immediately remove any worn heavy gear within their gear grid.

Q: Can a survivor with Sweet Battle without access to the Surge survival action perform Surge?.
A: Yes. Sweet Battle states "you may use Sweet Battle even if your settlement cannot normally surge. You may also use Sweet Battle when you have no survival and/or cannot spend survival. This does not let you surge more than once per round."

Q: The rulebook states that survivors are always in the monster's field of view unless they are in the monster's blind spot or the monster's line of sight is blocked. The FAQ suggests that a survivor on a Giant Stone Face can be both in the monster's field of view and blind spot at the same time. How can this be?.
A: The FAQ entry is an obsolete one from an earlier version of the game. The Giant Stone Face terrain has an explicit rule that "monsters may always draw a line of sight to [survivors atop the Giant Stone Face]". Thus, a survivor atop a Giant Stone Face is always in the monster's field of view, unless they are standing in the monster's blind spot.

Q: When performing a Forest Run during a Bloom People campaign, can players include the Bleeding Corpse Lily strange resource when drawing random Flower Resources?.
A: Yes.

Q: Heart Flute states “You play a trill note. Select any Nemesis” to trigger a special showdown with. Does this include Core and Finale monsters? Does this include Nemeses not found in your campaign?.
A: No.

Q: The 6+ result of the Heart Flute innovation instructs you to add a special showdown with the selected nemesis at the highest level you have not yet faced to the timeline this year. Is this correct?.
A: This is a typographical error. The 6+ result of Heart Flute should read: "You play a trill note. Select any Nemesis monster. Add a Special Showdown with them (at the next highest level you have not yet faced) to the timeline this year. You cannot endeavor here again this phase.

Q: How often does Bloodthirsty gain a token?.
A: Any time a survivor suffers damage for any reason. For example, a survivor who suffers 2 hits of 1 damage from the White Lion’s Basic Action would put 2 tokens on Bloodthirsty. A survivor and their two adjacent survivors suffering damage from the danger seizure brain trauma would put 3 tokens on Bloodthirsty.

Q: How does Invincible interact with Devastating? How does it interact with automatic wounds?.
A: When the Butcher is wounded, roll 1d10. On a result of 8+, the wound attempt fails instead. Do not move any AI cards to the monster’s wound stack and perform any applicable monster reactions due to the failed wound attempt.

Q: Gloom Man states ”when you move, place yourself anywhere on the showdown board". Does this include all movement (e.g.- spending movement, knockback, etc.)?.
A: Yes.

Q: None of the individual pieces that grant the Rolling Armor Set Bonus have the armor keyword. Does that mean survivors can have the pieces of gear in their gear grid even when effects such as Extreme Heat prevent survivors from wearing armor with specific keywords?.
A: Yes.

Q: The Outfit special rule states "This completes an armor set if you're wearing the rest of the set and it shares a material keyword with the missing armor gear." Can this be used with the Rolling Armor Set Bonus?.
A: Outfit serves as a replacement for another piece of armor gear. As none of the individual pieces that grant the Rolling Armor Set Bonus are armor gear, none of them can be replaced using Outfit.

Q: How do hits occurring outside of attack profiles work?.
A: Rules for how hits outside of attack profiles work can be found on pg. 193 of the Core Rulebook.

Q: Does Spinning Halberd affect ammo? Does it affect wounds that occur from non-ranged sources that narratively occur from a distance (e.g.- thrown Founding Stone, Deathpact)?.
A: Ammo inherits the range of the weapon they are ammo for. For example, a Claw Head Arrow inheriting the range of an Arc Bow in the survivor's gear grid has Range 6. Attacks made with the "Range: X" special rule are ranged attacks. Spinning Halberd does not affect wounds that occur from non-ranged sources. However, players may come to a narrative consensus that an effect will not affect the monster while Spinning Halberd is in play due to its "ranged" nature.

Q: Is there timing restrictions for naming an unnamed survivor?.
A: No, unless an effect explicitly states otherwise

Q: Can survivors use Secret Fighting Arts when frenzied?.
A: No.

Q: The flee brain trauma directs players to suffer knockback equal to their movement towards the closest board edge. If the survivor is already adjacent to the board edge, how do you resolve the knockback?.
A: If knockback or monster movement starts at a showdown board edge and would go off it, instead move along the board edge (see Core Game Rulebook pg. 72 for a further clarifying diagram).

Q: If a monster is standing in between a survivor and the board edge nearest to the survivor for the purposes of the flee brain trauma, what happens when that survivor suffers flee?.
A: The survivor suffers knockback equal to their movement towards the nearest board edge, into the monster. If a survivor would suffer knockback into a monster, treat the tiles the monster occupies as impassable terrain. The survivor suffers collision and stops their movement in the last space before the monster.

Q: Can you obtain multiple copies of gear like Scoopy Club and Ancient Root if you fulfill the conditions to gain the gear multiple times?.
A: Yes.

Q: Are pieces of gear with attack profiles that do not have the weapon keyword (e.g.- Bone Sickle, Corsair Coat) considered weapons?.
A: No.

Q: Does the Corsair Coat attack if the survivor wearing it dashes into a space out of range of the Corsair Coat?.
A: No.

Q: What facets of the survivor are considered permanent attributes?.
A: A survivor's permanent attributes are their: movement, accuracy, strength, evasion, speed, and luck.

Q: Do armor points accrued from effects (e.g.- Shrine, Crystal Skin) count as "wearing" armor for the purposes of effects that account for wearing armor gear?.
A: No.

Q: Can the Silk Nest terrain tile be archived during a showdown with Spidicules?.
A: The Silk Nest terrain tile has a typographical error. It should have the Indestructible special rule.

Q: If a monster is instructed to move or full move to/towards something (e.g.- Move & Attack Target, Screaming Antelope’s Graze) does the monster end its movement adjacent to or on top of the target?.
A: The monster ends its move adjacent to the target, facing the target.

Q: If there are multiple copies of the same weapon in your gear grid, and the copy you have designated to provide benefits is archived, can you designate another copy?.
A: Yes.

Q: Can the Manhunter AI Piercing Blow archive indestructible terrain?.
A: No.

Q: Is rolling on the Basic Hunt Event Table considered rolling on a table?.
A: Yes.

Q: Can Otherworldly Luck be used to avoid the Harvester Hunt Event by changing a Hunt Event Table roll result of 10 to 11?.
A: Harvester cannot be avoided in any way. 

Q: Does healing a permanent injury also remove the penalties incurred from having that permanent injury?.
A: Yes. (e.g.- A survivor that has -4 permanent accuracy and is retired solely due to having two blind permanent injuries would only have -1 permanent accuracy and no longer be retired if one of their blind permanent injuries is cured, a survivor that cannot use fighting arts due to a hamstrung permanent injury would be able to use fighting arts again if their hamstrung permanent injury is cured, etc.)

Q: What are “indirect activations”?.
A: Indirect activations refer to any effect that causes a piece of gear to activate that is not present on the gear itself. This includes effects such as Charge, Pounce, Skewer, Blood Paint, etc. Cumbersome is a gear special rule that places an additional activation restriction (survivors must spend movement and activation to activate Cumbersome gear) on the gear unless it is activated through an indirect activation. Indirect activations do not bypass other additional activation restrictions (e.g.- Sentient) unless they are explicitly stated to be able to do so.

Q: Charge does not mention attacking with a weapon, but does not mention you must activate the weapon first. Does that mean that you do not activate a weapon when you attack with it using Charge?.
A: No. Attacking with a weapon is activating the weapon for the purposes of attacking. If a survivor is unable to activate a weapon due to an activation restriction (e.g.- Sentient), the are unable to attack with it. 

Q: Are Saviors immune to King’s Curse?.
A: No. (The FAQ suggesting otherwise is an obsolete entry from a previous version of the game.)

Q: Is the Virulent Incantation card correct?.
A: There are two typographical errors On Virulent Incantation. The statement “Target a random survivor. Attack target, then discard this card.” should read as “Target a random survivor. Attack target.” In addition, the attack profile should not have an After Damage trigger.

Q: How does the Immovable Object secret fighting art work?.
A: There is a typographical error on Immovable Object. It should read as: “If you are in an otherwise unoccupied space, you stand firm in the face of any force. You cannot be knocked down and may ignore knockback.” An otherwise unoccupied space is determined by whether or not the space is empty of any other models, tiles, tokens, and terrain if the survivor is not occupying the space. This means that Immovable Object is not applicable when a survivor is occupying a space that is occupied by another survivor, a space with terrain (whether it is impassable like Stone Columns or terrain that survivors are able to occupy the same space with like Tall Grass), a space with a token on it, a space that is occupied by the monster, etc. 

Q: A survivor with Immovable Object suffers bash and knockback 10 while standing on terrain. In the midst of their knockback, they move onto an otherwise unoccupied space. What happens?.
A: Immovable Object does not retroactively prevent effects that occurred while it was not applicable. Even though the survivor is now in a position where they cannot be knocked down and may ignore knockback due to the effects of Immovable Object, they are in the midst of resolving an effect that occurred when they were not immune to being knocked down or knocked back and must finish resolving the effect. The survivor finishes the knockback effect and remains knocked down.

Q: Is a survivor affected by Whiplash if they are in the monster’s blind spot?.
A: No. If a survivor is considered to be in the monster’s blind spot (e.g.- standing in the appropriate positioning, Zero Presence, etc.), they will not receive bleeding tokens due to Whiplash.

Q: Sometimes there are scenarios where direct contradictions arise within the rules (e.g.- Doomed prevents all actions while Warriors of the Sun- Reflection allows a survivor to dodge at any time, even while doomed). What should be done when such a scenario occurs?.
A: When conflict arises over direct contradictions in rules, apply specific rules found on cards and story events (e.g.- Warriors of the Sun- Reflection) before any rules found in the rulebook core rules sections (e.g.- Core Rules pg 75- Doomed). When contradictions arise between specific rules (e.g.- Path of Gloom and Stark Raving), rule against the survivors' favor.

Q: Does being able to dodge at any time mean that dodge can be performed without spending survival?.
A: No. Being able to dodge at any time is a modifying effect placed upon the dodge survival action that allows you to perform dodge on occasions when dodge would normally be prohibited (e.g.- while you are attacking, doomed, or otherwise unable to perform survival actions). It does not modify the definition of dodge beyond this, which consists of “when a survivor is hit, they may spend 1 survival to dodge, canceling a monster hit. After hit locations are rolled, but before any severe injury rolls, the survivor can dodge a hit of their choice.”

Q: Should survivors continue to track leftover armor points during the settlement phase? Can armor points from a previous lantern year stack with armor points generated for departing survivors?.
A: No. Armor points are not maintained during the settlement phase, and cannot be “carried over”.

Q: Does the 1-5 roll result on the Black Mask Innovation kill the endeavoring survivor?.
A: Yes.

Q: The Balcony and Throne terrain cards refer to the survivors standing. Does this refer to the gameplay sense of standing?.
A: Yes.

Q: When the Lion Knight performs Encore and is placed in the center of the showdown board, do the survivors that occupy those spaces suffer collision before being placed in the survivor starting spaces?.
A: No.

Q: The Brawler Armor set bonus states that the Skull Helm cannot be destroyed. Does this protection include effects other than its own effect?.
A: Yes.

Q: Certain Story Events have colored boxes that modify roll results if specific requirements are met. Are these effects additive, replacement effects, or context dependent?.
A: Roll result modifiers are context dependent. Steps are being taken in future products to be clear when a specific roll modifier is additive or a replacement effect.

Q: Does Screaming Oni Armor Flay turn 1s into Perfect hits if they are the highest roll, or are they still automatic failures?.
A: Flay treats the two highest attack rolls of an attack with a dagger as Perfect hits, regardless of numerical value. If the two highest attack rolls of the attack are 1s, they will still hit and count as Perfect hits for the purposes of any effects that trigger on Perfect hits.

Q: Does a survivor returned to the settlement prematurely via a stated effect during the Hunt or Showdown (e.g.- Run Away, Phoenix's Analtorium) count as a returning survivor?.
A: No. Survivors prematurely returned to the settlement are not treated as returning survivors unless explicitly stated.

Q: How does doomed work?.
A: Doomed prevents a survivor from performing any actions until they are no longer doomed. This includes using fighting arts, knowledges, abilities, weapon proficiency, armor set bonuses, survival actions, spending movement or activation, gear special rules, resource effects, etc.

Q: One of the ingredients to craft Fetorsaurus, the Sleeping Virus Flower, is Cursed. How does this work?.
A: Players may spend the Sleeping Virus Flower to craft Fetorsaurus as if it were not Cursed. A future product will update how crafting with the Sleeping Virus Flower occurs.

Q: When a disemboweled survivor dies at the end of the Showdown after defeating a monster, does the Showdown end in Victory or Defeat? What happens when a Victory occurs with no living survivors?.
A: A disemboweled survivor dying during the Aftermath after defeating a monster causes the Showdown to end in Victory with no living survivors. During such an occurrence, resolve all applicable effects (e.g.- adding the monster to the Defeated Monsters section of the settlement record sheet) while disregarding any that cannot occur (e.g.- survivors gaining Hunt XP, as there are no survivors alive to do so). As all survivors have perished during the Showdown Phase, any resources they were carrying or would gain from Rewards are lost.

Q: Should expansions use the Rules Update for Special Showdowns found in the core game rulebook?.
A: Yes.

Q: Is the Beast Kunai a weapon? It does not have the weapon keyword, but has the dagger keyword..
A: The Beast Kunai is not a weapon for keyword purposes (e.g.- Giant Mouth Reflex Reaction). It is a dagger for keyword purposes (e.g.- Aichmophobia, Weapon Proficiency).

Q: How does the armor keyword interact with Accessory on the same item?.
A: Survivors can only wear one piece of armor at each location, even if the gear has the Accessory special rule. A piece of gear with the armor keyword and the Accessory special rule will be affected by both effects that pertain to Accessories and effects that pertain to armor.

Q: If a survivor is eligible for multiple Armor Set Bonuses, are they able to claim all of them together?.
A: Yes.

Q: Under what circumstances can a survivor use lifetime rerolls/reroll tokens? Can a roll result that has already been rerolled be rerolled again?.
A: Survivors with a lifetime reroll/reroll token can spend it to reroll any single roll result that they are present for. This includes any dice that survivor rolls (e.g.- a d10 roll for the survivor, a d10 roll for the monster while the survivor has the monster controller tile, a hit location roll, etc.), and any dice that survivor is deemed "present" for according to narrative consensus. Players are recommended to suggest that a survivor is "present" only when they have sufficient narrative cause to do so. After a roll result has been rerolled, the new result must be kept and cannot be rerolled again.

Q: White Lion hit locations use the phrasing "any survivors passed over suffer "Grab". Is there any mechanical difference between being passed over and colliding? Does the White Lion Grabbing survivors circumvent/prevent other effects that occur during collision from happening (e.g.- knocked down from collision, knockback 5 from the monster ending its movement on the survivor, Amber Poleaxe's special rule, Tumble, etc.)?.
A: No. No.

Q: When a survivor has the ability to gain monster level weapon experience after a nemesis fight (such as axe proficiency for the Butcher), do they need to be eligible (have wounded a monster at least once with the weapon type), to gain the proficiency?.
A: Yes. A survivor must still be eligible to gain weapon-specific weapon proficiency from the Aftermath of a nemesis fight.

Q: When do you choose a quarry to hunt? How do limitations like Flower Addiction, Megalophobia, and Dead Guardian affect your quarry choice?.
A: Players choose a quarry to hunt at the beginning of the Hunt Phase, immediately after Table Setup, before departing on the hunt. Survivors may choose a quarry from the list of available monsters on the Quarry List of their settlement, and choose a monster level based on the levels available to their settlement. Effects like Flower Addiction, Megalophobia, and Dead Guardian restrict the quarry you are able to choose during this step. If these restrictions prevent the survivors from choosing all options that are available to them, the hunt ends in failure.

Q: Do resource effects that occur within settlement storage (e.g.- Gibbering Haremite, Lump of Atnas) trigger multiple times if there are multiple of those resources within the settlement storage?.
A: Yes. Lump of Atnas has a typographical error. The text on Lump of Atnas should read as: "At the start of the settlement phase, if there are 5+ Lumps of Atnas in settlement storage, their scent draws a survivor, sniffing through the darkness. Gain +1 population with a random disorder. Gain this benefit once per settlement phase, regardless of how many Lumps are in storage."

Q: What happens when a settlement consists of only 4 departing survivors and the Gibbering Haremite causes the settlement to suffer -1 population?.
A: The settlement suffers -1 population, causing the settlement to consist of only 3 departing survivors.

Q: Can survivors archive Vital gear as normal?.
A: Yes.

Q: Final Lantern has the "other" keyword. What happens when a Savior or survivor with the Superstitious disorder acquires it outside of the Settlement Phase?.
A: Saviors may not wear any gear with the "other" keyword due to Life Exchange. The Final Lantern is not a piece of armor or an accessory and is therefore not worn. Superstitious survivors cannot depart or activate "other" gear in their gear grid. This does not preclude them from acquiring the Final Lantern after departure, and the rules associated with the Final Lantern do not involve activation. Both Superstitious survivors and Saviors can acquire the Final Lantern as normal outside of the Settlement Phase.

Q: What specific resource do you gain from the 2+ roll result of the Dead Warrior Hunt Event?.
A: You gain a Monster Bone basic resource.

Q: Should Aichmophobia be extended to other weapon types aside from the currently listed ones?.
A: No.

Q: How do the timings of "After Hit" and "dodge" interact?.
A: After Hits effects occur after determining hits from a monster's attack roll, before rolling hit location dice. Dodging occurs after rolling hit location dice, before damage. As After Hit effects trigger before survivors have the opportunity to dodge, survivors cannot use dodge to circumvent After Hit effects.

Q: How does Graze function if there are no Acanthus Plants on the showdown board?.
A: The Screaming Antelope will full move forward in a straight line.

Q: What does Sideswipe do?.
A: What does it do indeed.

Q: Are the Vault Key Earrings intended to work with a survivor with the Fear of the Dark disorder?.
A: Yes.

Q: The fighting art Blotted Out states "When you suffer a brain trauma, gain a bleeding token," What does this mean?.
A: Whenever a survivor with Blotted Out suffers a brain trauma, they gain a bleeding token as well.

Q: Can a survivor Tumble while knocked down?.
A: Yes. If a survivor successfully tumbles out of harms way while knocked down, they are placed standing on the closest free space outside of the collision path.

Q: Does Frenzy prevent all fighting arts from working?.
A: Yes. For example, a frenzied survivor with Tough would not add +1 to their result when rolling on a severe injury table, nor would a frenzied survivor with Rhythm Chaser remove all of their +1 evasion tokens when knocked down if they do not have an instrument in their gear grid.

Q: When a science endeavor is prevented, does that only prevent endeavoring from those specific cards (e.g.- Albedo), or does it prevent endeavoring of any kind that requires a science innovation (e.g.- Leathermaking at the Leather Worker)?.
A: When a specific type of endeavor is prevented, survivors may not perform any kind of endeavor that requires an innovation of that specific type.

Q: The Armored Fist fighting art requires fist & tooth proficiency to work. If a fist & tooth master has this fighting art and decides to switch to another weapon proficiency, will Armored Fist continue to work?.
A: Yes. Weapon masters and specialists are proficient at the weapons they master/specialize in.

Q: The Ambidextrous fighting art cannot be used if there are shields, two-handed, or heavy gear in your gear grid. Is this a rule of Ambidextrous, or are these restrictions an inherent aspect of the Paired keyword?.
A: The restrictions on Ambidextrous pertain only to the fighting art.

Q: How does Clarity of Darkness/Path of Gloom interact with effects like Husk of Destiny or Stark Raving that make you "always insane"?.
A: When direct contradictions arise between specific rules, as is with the case of Path of Gloom and Stark Raving/Husk of Destiny, rule against the survivors' favor. A survivor who is "always insane" and "not insane unless they have 5+ insanity" is not insane unless they have 5+ insanity.

Q: Under what circumstances do you gain the benefits of your settlement's Death Principle]?.
A: Do not gain the benefits of your settlement's Death Principle from survivors that are exiled, leave the settlement, or cease to exist. In cases where a survivor is stated to have both "died" and "been exiled/left the settlement/ceased to exist" (e.g.- King's Curse), do not gain the benefits of your settlement's Death Principle. Gain the benefits of your settlement's Death Principle from all other survivors that die, including from population loss, unless explicitly stated otherwise.

Q: What constitutes a "cold" hunt event as per Grim Muffler?.
A: Whether a Hunt Event can be designated as "cold" should be determined by narrative consensus within your play group, similarly to determining a group's "favorite survivor" for Hunt Reenactment, or whether or not the story of a Weird Dream is "well told". Players are recommended to suggest that a hunt event is "cold" only when they have sufficient narrative cause to do so, and should refrain from suggesting any hunt event that causes survival loss (e.g.- Basic Hunt Event 20: Dry Lands) is a "cold" hunt event.

Q: Under what circumstances do the special rules of a weapon apply outside of when it is activated?.
A: The special rules of a weapon are always only applicable when the weapon is activated unless 1) the rule specifies an effect that can only occur within a timing outside of the showdown, or 2) the rule is explicitly stated to be applicable during a timing outside of activations. Examples of the following are:
1) Round Leather Shield (Adding armor points to hit locations occurs during Prepare Departing Survivors in the Settlement Phase), Vespertine Foil (Spending a resource or archiving the weapon occurs during the beginning of the Settlement Phase), Digging Claw (Rerolling on the Mineral Gathering Story Event occurs during the Hunt Phase).
2) Amber Poleaxe (the effect of the monster suffering a wound is tied to the timing of "the monster colliding with you"), Fetorsaurus (the effect of reducing is tied to the timing of "while you are carrying Fetorsaurus"), Scoopy Club (the effect of filling the club and gaining the ability to Daze monsters when wounding with Scoopy Club is tied to the timing of "when you vomit, are vomited on, or are adjacent to vomit.").

Q: Does using the Legs Locked Pulse discovery count as your once per round usage of the Death Die?.
A: Yes.

Q: Can you use Metabolic Surrender when you do not have the Death Die?.
A: No. You can use Metabolic Surrender at any time during the showdown while you are in possession of the Death Die.

Q: The Ashen Claw Strain adds both the Armored Fist fighting art and the Fiddler Crab Spider vermin to your game. When starting a new campaign, is the Fiddler Crab Spider permanently included as a vermin resource, or is it only added if Armored Fist is also present in that campaign?.
A: Fiddler Crab Spider should only be added to your campaign if Armored Fist is also present.

Q: The ability "Reflection" states that you may "dodge at any time, and as many times as you like each round". Does this allow you to dodge while you are attacking or doomed?.
A: Yes. Reflective allows you to perform dodge during timings when you are normally prohibited. Note that Reflective does not allow you to avoid damage that dodge does not normally prevent, such as damage outside of attack actions. In addition, being able to dodge while doomed does not allow you to perform any other action aside from dodging while you are doomed (e.g.- you cannot activate the Rawhide Armor Set Bonus effect while dodging when you are doomed).

Q===. How do you perform a Spiral Formation Attack? Can you perform a Spiral Formation Attack and a Combined Attack (Principle: Bonding- Devoted Union) simultaneously?===

Spiral Formation currently suffers from timing ambiguity. Its text will be updated to read: "During a survival opportunity, if the survivors are standing in this formation, you may spend 1 survival to activate a weapon. This attack ignores all monster reactions. Limit, once per showdown." in a future Update pack. 

Spiral Formation and Combined Attack are both types of attacks, rather than attack modifiers. Different types of attacks cannot be used simultaneously (e.g.- Combined Attack and Charge). However, survivors may have multiple attack modifiers simultaneously affecting their attack (e.g.- Attacking with Pounce using Fist & Tooth can gain both the benefits of Monster Claw Style and an Attack Assist from Synchronized Strike).

Q: What is the intended interaction between the Speaker Cult Knife and abilities like Acid Palm and Monster Claw Style? Do such abilities buff the Speaker Cult Knife because it is a "Fist & Tooth weapon", or are they only mean to apply specifically to the "Fist & Tooth" weapon survivors naturally have?.
A: Abilities like Acid Palm and Monster Claw Style apply to all weapons with the Fist & Tooth weapon type, including the Speaker Cult Knife.

Q: How can two survivors spend simultaneously in order to perform a "Principle: Bonding- Devoted Union" combined attack? If a combined attack draws the trap, is the full attack cancelled?.
A: Both survivors must have an activation to spend at the time of declaring a combined attack in order to do so. This is most commonly achieved by having one survivor perform the surge survival action during the other's act. If a combined attack draws a monster's Trap, the entire combined attack is cancelled. The partners choose which survivor "attempts to wound" the Trap. The chosen survivor is treated as the attacker for the purposes of the Trap.

Q: The Lonely Tree expansion tells you to remove the Basic Hunt event from the game after resolving the event, but the terrain card remains in the deck, so you can still randomly draw it. This allows you to fight the Lonely Tree multiple times. Is this intended?.
A: Yes.

Q: Can a survivor be encouraged at any time, even if not knocked down, or may only a knocked down survivor be encouraged?.
A: Survivors can only encourage knocked down survivors unless an effect explicitly allows them to encourage in other contexts.

Q: Is the Watcher intended to not give Weapon Proficiency or Hunt XP?.
A: Yes.

Q: The settlement event Heat Wave has a Lingering Effect that allows you to spend 1 endeavor to Find Fluid. The 6-7 result of this effect reads "you may depart with heavy gear normally." Who is this "you" referring to?.
A: The "you" referred to in this roll result is the survivor nominated to spend the endeavor to Find Fluid. Only that survivor may depart with heavy gear without setting their survival to 0 after applying all bonuses.

Q: Should survivors find themselves in a brand new settlement with a Final Lantern, can they eventually gain another one? Do the effects of multiple Final Lanterns stack? Does the Lantern Research from their previous settlement carry over?.
A: Yes, survivors may have multiple Final Lanterns. The effects of multiple Final Lanterns do not stack, as you cannot have multiple instances of the same survivor status. Lantern Research level is tied to your current settlement. A settlement with a Final Lantern begins at Lantern Research Level 1. Without access to Lantern Research - Pulse Discoveries, a settlement cannot increase their Lantern Research above 1.

The Thief is a Generic Hero Class resin miniature.

Store Description.
The Thief is the 3rd result of a collaboration between Adam & Lokman, exploring some well established tropes in fantasy art. Originally intended as a small line of Generic Hero Classes, the results were so compelling and un-generic, each hero's appearance told so many exciting stories that we wanted to integrate them into the KD world but so far nothing concrete has emerged.

Maybe she is a frantic Savior's painting come to life. Or perhaps she comes from a small village at the center of a rainbow-hued swamp that absorbs the life of its inhabitants for generations before it awakes and paints a tapestry across the horizon. She could also be a renegade from a far developed Sun Stalker settlement. One day we'll set the record straight.

Store Description.
The Relic Knight has lost control to the personality living inside his relic sword. The relic sword has no consideration for the lost knight's body. Wanderers are strangers who emerge from the darkness to call your settlement home. During their stay, they will share their story with the settlement.

A wanderer brings the artifacts of their previous life: new Gear, Disorders, Fighting Arts, and more. While they live in your settlement, they can use these to hunt and fight alongside the survivors.

Campaigns can have only one wanderer. Even after they leave the settlement or die, another will not appear.

Adding Wanderers to Your Campaign.
Each wanderer has an accompanying book with rules, an introduction, and further content that tells their story throughout their stay.

Wanderers will join a campaign through an introduction story. The wanderer's rules specify when to add the introduction to your settlement's Timeline.

Rules.
When a wanderer joins the settlement, create a new survivor record sheet for them and increase your settlement's population. Use the starting attributes and details listed in the wanderer's rulebook.

Disposition.
Disposition is a wanderer trait that represents their feelings toward their adopted settlement. It can increase or decrease during the campaign and can be negative. Keep track of a wanderer's disposition on their survivor record sheet. A wanderer's disposition toward your settlement greatly influences the results of their story!

Outsider.
Wanderers arrive with their own life experiences. They do not gain the benefits of being born in your settlement (e.g., principles, innovations applying to newborn survivors, etc).

In all other ways, while living in your settlement they are like any other survivor. They can depart (gaining departing survivor effects), gain Hunt XP, contribute and use endeavors, be nominated for story events, adhere to the settlement's survival limit, etc.

Wandering Arc Survivors.
Wanderers can be arc survivors who join the campaigns of other survivors. Rules are included for a wanderer's life and development in different types of settlements.

If a wanderer is an arc survivor, they will have an accompanying philosophy unique to their outlook, as well as Hunt XP milestones that indicate when they ponder their philosophy, increasing its rank.

If wandering arc survivors join an arc survivor settlement, their knowledges are added to the settlement's knowledge deck as the wanderers gain them.

Arc survivors living outside arc settlements will not gain benefits of living with a Forum or other arc survivors. Instead, they will gain knowledge only through the course of their own philosophy.

A tribe that has found a harsh but harmonious existence under the oldest sun. The warrior young are raised alongside the sun's offspring in the sacred spawning pools. The few that survive to adulthood among the voracious brood do so by learning from the sun's infants.

The grown warriors become masters of stealth, developing power over the light, bending and shifting beams of light to hide in plain sight. Their garments woven of valuable prismatic fibers that help the warriors remain invisible in the darkness and in the light.

Contents.
1 x Resin Warrior of the Sun Male
1 x Kingdom Death 30mm Base and Insert
6" x 4" Print of the Original Concept Artwork on heavy card stock.
Character Card

The Wet Nurse is a limited release resin miniature.

Store Description.
The Wet Nurse is a single minded monster that serves the Entity of the Holy Lands. Its only purpose is to nourish the creatures born in the Holy Lands with the molten milk it produces. This is the nutrition that carries within it the imperatives and instincts to serve the Entity of the Holy Lands. Infants taken from their captive mothers at birth are nursed by the Wet Nurses to create the mindless shambling masses of Holy Landers that live in the Entity's fiefdom.

Contents.
1 x Wet Nurse high quality resin miniature
3 x accompanying suffering pregnant women that complete the tableau
6" x 4" Matte art print
Character art card

'White Box' is a catch-all term used to refer to small, hard plastic and resin miniature sets that are released along side rules that can be implemented into the Kingdom Death: Monster Core Game, experimental rules or promotional cards.

Many of the models feature survivors that are canon within the world of Kingdom Death, while others are simply lighthearted pinup models.

Official Content White Boxes.
These box sets contain rules that can be directly implemented into the core game, and should be considered official content (note: the model itself may not be canon to the world of Kingdom Death).

Beta Rules "White Boxes".
Announced during the Black Friday 2021 Kickstarter Update, these are new releases of canon Kingdom Death characters featuring beta cards with square-cut corners. These miniatures come in the standard brown craft boxes that Kingdom Death Limited Releases are packaged in, but feature additional content for use in-game. While these miniatures do receive limited Deathgrey and First Run editions, they are also released in a "Made to Order Encore Edition" to meet demand. The White Lion is probably the most straightforward of all the monsters you can choose to face in Kingdom Death: Monster, but that doesn't mean that it's a cake walk. 

Hunt Events.
The Lion's hunt events are generally pretty positive, which means that in most cases you want to experience as many as possible. Compared to other hunts, even the negative effects are very minor. There are just a few exceptions, which will be mentioned below.

Things which you may experience on a Lion Hunt:
Minor brain damage
Minor event damage
Ambush
Minor insanity
Minor understanding
Minor courage
Ammonia Innovation
Lion Claw resource
Major additional resources

Ground Fighting.
There is a particular hunt event which can be deadly if unprepared for, which is where the Lion begins with Ground Fighting in play. To an early survivor, having to trigger ground fighting by running up and trying to wound the lion will result in significant damage being returned for not much gain.

It is for this reason that Bone Darts or Cat Gut Bow are preferred by White Lion hunters, because the lion will not react or move until a wound is scored. This means that ground fighting can effectively be nullified without damage to the survivors.

The White Lion Cub.
This particular hunt event allows for the survivors access to a large amount of bonus resources through killing the cub, which can be a major boost during the early game item progression. When choosing this option, just make sure that you can handle an Enraged lion, or a lion Ambush if it's close.

The Showdown.
For most level 1 engagements, getting in the blind spot and pummeling the lion is a pretty effective strategy, and will serve you for the first few hunts. Once you start considering fighting level 2 lions, you'll need to consider the more detailed information below.

The Lion's ability to grab and pull survivors apart can mean that you're left to spend turns chasing the lion around, missing out on precious attacks to contribute damage to the monster. Gaining the ability to dash helps to mitigate this quite effectively, as you can chase down the lion after it has grabbed someone, or alternatively dash away after an attack to prevent the grab from the Level 2+ Lion's Cunning passive. Avoid attacking from the front of the Lion to keep from being caught by its full move forward and grab reactions.

The Lion has mostly failure reactions, many of them resulting in a counter attack. For this reason, it is often better to miss with an attack than hit the Lion but fail to wound it. Eschew high speed but low strength weapons that are likely to trigger multiple return attacks.

Good gear for White Lion hunters.
The following items have additional value during a White Lion hunt are listed below:

Exploits.
This section deals with situations which can arise which feel more mechanical, and less fluent in the game flavor. This is where you find the most variance in how players resolve the situation. Some choose to be purist and go by the rules, and others try to play by the flavor of the game and stop some situations before they get out of hand.

Infinite Understanding - Showdown**.
This exploit requires the basic AI card Combo Claw to be in the AI deck, and to have performed a critical wound on the Lion's Strange Hand. 

Every time the combo claw AI comes up, instead of attacking as it has lost its hand, an adjacent survivor gains +1 understanding.

This means that with a Cat Eye Circlet, and Rawhide Headband, you can make it much more likely, or even 100% chance to combo claw repeatedly. In this case you can just leave your survivors next to the Lion and get everyone to 10 understanding for the White Secret story event.

This can also be done with the missing jaw on Beasts Maw and Chomp

This has since been changed to a once per life time in 1.5 release

is a Watcher hit location card found in the Kingdom Death: Monster Core Game.
Card Text.
TRAP! - Reshuffle Hit Location Deck.
If Black Out and White Out are drawn during the same attack, the attacker suffers the head explosion severe head injury! This cannot be avoided in anyway. After, place the Watcher in the center of the showdown board.

Otherwise, all survivors are doomed.

Move the Watcher to the center of the showdown board. Turn to face the attacker.

Intimidate the attacker. They suffer 3 brain damage, are knocked down, and gain the Stolen Dreams survivor status card.

The White Speaker Boss is a limited release resin miniature.

Store Description.
The White Speaker Boss wears the crown of Phoenix chick feathers, each one a memory of an unlived life, the impossible story of her past. She stands in the ritual baths of blood, reciting the treasure of her insight to her sisters. These stories of the might-have-been give her cult uncanny luck in the what-is-now.

The White Speaker Nico is a limited release resin miniature.

Store Description.
Long ago, the White Speaker cult's savagery threatened the few enclaves of human civilization. The Order of Twilight Knights rose up nearly destroying the cult. Now, small covens of White Speakers can be found meeting in abandoned places, sharing the secrets of their blood magic, passed on from one White Speaker to another through intricate tales, whispered and screamed in frenzied, transcendental rituals.

Nico is a second White Speaker in the Kingdom Death range. She represents more aspects of the White Speaker cult, their ritual garb and weapons.

Contents.
1 x Resin White Speaker Nico Miniature
3 Head Options, 2 Cape Options, 6 Hand / Arm Options
1 x Hard plastic 30mm insert and base
Large matte art print
Character Card
